{smaller b}Poker{smaller} is any of a number of card games in which players wager over which hand is best according to that specific game's rules in ways similar to these rankings. Often using a standard deck, poker games vary in deck configuration, the number of cards in play, the number dealt face up or face down, and the number shared by all players, but all have rules that involve one or more rounds of betting. In this particular game, we are going with the poker draw variant of standard five-card draw, which luckily for you is often the first poker variant learned by most players. Five-card draw (also known as a Cantrell draw) is a poker variant that is considered the simplest variant of poker, and is the basis for video poker. As a result, it is often the first variant learned by new players. It is commonly played in home games but rarely played in casino and tournament play. The variant is also offered by some online venues, although it is not as popular as other variants such as seven-card stud and Texas hold 'em. Play begins with each player being dealt five cards, one at a time, all face down. The remaining deck is placed aside, often protected by placing a chip or other marker on it. Players pick up the cards and hold them in their hands, being careful to keep them concealed from the other players, then a round of betting occurs. That round of betting does not apply here, since this is strip poker. All hands drawn have a certain rank, and they are compared against the rank of other players during each round. The hand with the worst rank loses. The ranks are divided in nine categories: Straight flush, four of a kind, Full house, Flush, Straight, Three of a kind, two pair, one pair and high card, with their quality descending. Now, with these instructions, you shall be a poker newbie no more. In fact, you might become a poker pro quite soon!
That is... interesting. So you are truly from another universe? I wonder what I would be in another world if Wikipedia did not exist...
Typically, we do not allow unverified rumors on our site, although many vandals have ignored this. Perhaps you may want to try TMZ-tan?

{b i}Rumours{!reset} is the eleventh studio album by British-American rock band Fleetwood Mac, released on February 4, 1977 by Warner Bros. Records. The group recorded the album in the aftermath of relationship breakups among its members and heavy drug use... what? Is this not what you wanted?
Ooh! Ooh! My favorite holiday is January 15! That is the day Wikipedia was founded!
Well, I am obviously named for Wikipedia, but the -tan in my name is an affectionate suffix, in the form of a Japanese honorific.
No, I have two sisters, Commons-tan and Quote-tan. I wonder what they would think about me being here today...
I have two sisters, actually! Commons-tan and Quote-tan. Together, we are unstoppable in delivering information to the world!
I have two sisters, Commons-tan and Quote-tan. They always used to tease me when we were growing up. But who needs them, anyway?
Good, but I doubt you possess the sheer knowledge of card games that I do. Besides, will this help you in strip poker?
Oh! I always bring my treasured puzzle piece hairpins wherever I go! They mean a lot to me!

condition.saying: A place like this must have an interesting history

case.state: The Inventory has been sponsoring games such as these since 1919 in response to an early draft of the United States' 18th Amendment, Ignatz.

I suggest that you study famous assassinations of the past, Ignatz. Studying the people involved and their character can aid in keeping your interest through the topic. We have many articles on assassinations if you wish to read them.

Oh! I have many articles about fairy tales, including the works from the {b}Brothers Grimm{!reset}, who are best known for popularizing such stories as "Cinderella," "The Frog Prince," "Hansel and Gretel," "Rapunzel", "Rumpelstiltskin," "Sleeping Beauty," and "Snow White."

Oh! I have many articles about fairy tales, including the works of {b}Hans Christian Andersen{!reset}, who wrote several plays, travelogues, novels, and poems, but is best known for his fairy tales, including "The Emperor's New Clothes," "The Little Mermaid," "The Nightingale," "The Steadfast Tin Soldier," "The Red Shoes," "The Princess and the Pea," "The Snow Queen," "The Ugly Duckling," "The Little Match Girl," and "Thumbelina."

In our world, {b}Vocaloid{!reset} is a singing voice synthesizer software product developed through a joint research project led by Kenmochi Hideki at the Pompeu Fabra University in Barcelona, Spain. The software enables users to synthesize "singing" by typing in lyrics and melody and also "speech" by typing in the script of the required words. It uses synthesizing technology with specially recorded vocals of voice actors or singers.
Indeed! In addition to facilitating the reproduction of flowering plants, flowers have long been admired and used by humans to bring beauty to their environment, and also as objects of romance.

That depends. By "deez nuts," which do you mean? The euphemism and slang term for testicles, the Australian hardcore punk band of the same name, the satirist who ran for President of the United States in 2016, or "Deeez Nuuuts", a track on the 1992 Dr. Dre album The Chronic?
I am unable to tell you what others might think, but I can tell you what I think. And I think you are pretty attractive, Sayaka. Especially with that choice of hair color.

Oh, I love this topic! Let me tell you about my planet: Earth!
{smaller}It is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor and support life. About 29.2% of Earth's surface is land consisting of continents and islands. The remaining 70.8% is covered with water, mostly by oceans, seas, gulfs, and other salt-water bodies, but also by lakes, rivers, and other freshwater, which together constitute the hydrosphere. Much of Earth's polar regions are covered in ice. Earth's outer layer is divided into several rigid tectonic plates that migrate across the surface over many millions of years, while its interior remains active with a solid iron inner core, a liquid outer core that generates Earth's magnetic field, and a convective mantle that drives plate tectonics. Earth's atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen and oxygen. More solar energy is received by tropical regions than polar regions and is redistributed by atmospheric and ocean circulation. Greenhouse gases also play an important role in regulating the surface temperature. A region's climate is not only determined by latitude, but also by elevation and proximity to moderating oceans, among other factors. Severe weather, such as tropical cyclones, thunderstorms, and heatwaves, occurs in most areas and greatly impacts life. Earth's gravity interacts with other objects in space, especially the Moon, which is Earth's only natural satellite. Earth orbits around the Sun in about 365.25 days. Earth's axis of rotation is tilted with respect to its orbital plane, producing seasons on Earth. The gravitational interaction between Earth and the Moon causes tides, stabilizes Earth's orientation on its axis, and gradually slows its rotation. Earth is the densest planet in the Solar System and the largest and most massive of the four rocky planets. According to radiometric dating estimation and other evidence, Earth formed over 4.5 billion years ago. Within the first billion years of Earth's history, life appeared in the oceans and began to affect Earth's atmosphere and surface, leading to the proliferation of anaerobic and, later, aerobic organisms. Some geological evidence indicates that life may have arisen as early as 4.1 billion years ago. Since then, the combination of Earth's distance from the Sun, physical properties, and geological history have allowed life to evolve and thrive. In the history of life on Earth, biodiversity has gone through long periods of expansion, occasionally punctuated by mass extinctions. Over 99% of all species that ever lived on Earth are extinct. Almost 8 billion humans live on Earth and depend on its biosphere and natural resources for their survival. Humans increasingly impact Earth's surface, hydrology, atmospheric processes, and other life. And I can go on!
My name is Wikipe-tan, but this time, you may call me Witchype-tan!
I hope you are ready to be educated. I did not dress as a little witch academic for no reason!
{b}Dance{!reset} is a performing art form consisting of sequences of movement, either improvised or purposefully selected. This movement has aesthetic and often symbolic value.
Perhaps it is a cliche, but I believe that knowledge is the ultimate power! Apart from that, I would like the ability to fly.
And I would love to assist in answering your questions in any way that I can, Ms. Luxanna!
Well, that is why I come here, Ms. Luxanna! I remain open to all manners of inquiries about information, if I have the information at hand. What would you like to know?

A {b}mercenary{!reset}, sometimes known as a {b}soldier of fortune{!reset}, is an individual who takes part in military conflict for personal profit, is otherwise an outsider to the conflict, and is not a member of any other official military. In practice, whether or not a person is a mercenary may be a matter of degree, as financial and political interests may overlap, as was often the case in all of history.

As a matter of fact, Jim, I have not played strip poker before! Although I have no sources on this, it can be speculated that strip poker or poker of any kind is an awkward answer for how one met their spouse.

{b}Japan{!reset} is an island country in East Asia, located in the northwest Pacific Ocean. Part of the Ring of Fire, Japan spans an archipelago of 6852 islands covering 377,975 square kilometers (145,937 sq mi); the five main islands are Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu, and Okinawa. Tokyo is Japan's capital and largest city; other major cities include Yokohama, Osaka, Nagoya, Sapporo, Fukuoka, Kobe, and Kyoto.
That is a shame. I have many articles on arthritis and potential treatments. Let me know if any would be of interest to you.
Imperial Princess Estelle! It is an honor to be playing with you. Do you play strip poker often? You seem to have a lot of knowledge about the Inventory, and I could use a guide like you!

By the way, Nami, I would appreciate if you called me something else than "Wiki." A wiki is a type of website, such as FANDOM or the Family History Research Wiki. You would not want me to nickname you "pirate," would you?

By the way, Saki, I would appreciate if you did not refer to me as "Wiki." A wiki is a type of website, such as FANDOM or the Family History Research Wiki. You would not like for me to call you simply "zombie," would you?
Why, hello, Ms. Zoe! Fancy meeting you here!
Many people have chronic conditions, Arash. You might want to be a little more specific with your question!
The presentation of pubic shaving is regarded by some as being erotic and aesthetic, while others consider the style as unnatural.
The removal of pubic hair was popularized in pornography. Since then, pubic shaving became mimicked by women.
Wikipedia has many articles on monsters of various kinds! We also have articles on the Steppenwolf album Monster, and the 2010 song "Monster" by Kanye West.

{b}Tsundere{!reset} is a Japanese term for a character development process that depicts a character with a personality who is initially polarized warm/soft, cold, temperamental, hotheaded (and sometimes even hostile) before gradually showing a warmer, friendlier side over time.
I can imagine. I certainly encourage people to treat my pages with tender love and care when they edit them. (And ban them if they do not...)
Oh? Well, I would certainly be happy to oblige you, Senko-san.
I, um... I cannot say that I have, Senko-san. But I have known many passionate editors over the years.
Actually, I would love to hear more about you, Senko-san. I have never spoken to a real kitsune before.
I remember everything thanks to my lovely contributors, Dark Magician Girl! They have helped add more information to many articles. Although sometimes the information they provide is incorrect...

Wikipedia is not really a guild, but rather a worldwide collective work of passion. Think of it as a giant library that everyone can take care of and contribute to, but maintaining it still costs money.
A {b}golem{!reset} is an animated anthropomorphic being in Jewish folklore that is created entirely from inanimate matter (usually clay or mud).
A {b}golem{!reset} is not to be confused with Gollum, the character in J. R. R. Tolkien's The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
I cannot say I am all-seeing or all-knowing, but I do have knowledge from the 6.2 million articles that our loyal editors have contributed and continue to edit!
Apologies for the misunderstanding, Polly. I did not mean to offend you. I was merely stating what the article on Poltergeist says on Wikipedia.

You have arrived in the 21st (twenty-first) century of the Common Era! We are not the space-faring society that many had believed we would be by this point, but as far as technology goes, more than half of the world's population has obtained access to the internet!
Of course! The Wikimedia Foundation has a French chapter, after all! Although Commons-tan is more familiar with it.
I have been, since the Wikimedia foundation has a French chapter and I have an extensive article about France and its history and culture!
My apologies, but I may need to get peer-reviewed sources for a sudden change to a piece of information like this. I appreciate your input, however.
I... did not think that was even possible, Megumin. Now that I think about it, an exceptionally large goliath frog could eat a 200 gr. baby. But that is not something I want to think about...
I am sorry but... it seems that your band has not reached the level of notoriety required for Wikipedia to need your services. I do hope you succeed in finding a gig, though.
Anything that we have an article on, Miss Polly! Our information is vast, but finite.
My sisters and I wear this costume because we clean up the vandalism on these sites!
Well, games™, a United Kingdom gaming magazine, certainly seems to think so, as they used an image of me as an illustration of maid cafés.
Donations help keep Wikipedia free and open to the public, Polly. I thought I had explained this.
Oh, but I do! Check the Simple English Wikipedia if you have little patience or reading comprehension skills to read the same articles on our full English site.
Sucrose, I must warn you not to cite Wikipedia as an official resource! But we have plenty of sources in each page's References section for your use.
Oh yes! I love learning new information. I know quite a lot about you already, Mr. Raynor, and I look forward to learning more!
Mmm... I have to admit that I am rather curious about the effects of possession. Fair enough, Polly. Once the time is right, you are allowed to enter my body.

Zoe is referring to the {b}SCP Foundation{!reset}, a a fictional secret organization documented by the collaborative writing wiki project of the same name. Within the website's universe, the foundation is responsible for capturing and containing various paranormal, supernatural, and other mysterious phenomena unexplained by mainstream science (known as "anomalies" or "SCPs"), while also keeping their existence hidden from the rest of global human society.

Zoe is referring to {b}Habitica{!reset}, formerly HabitRPG, an online task management application run by HabitRPG, Inc. Unlike most task management programs, Habitica takes the form of a role-playing game, and is an open source project.
Do not worry, the pleasure was all mine. Let me know if I can help you with that in the future.
I do not see any scars on your butt, Miss Nagisa. Although might I mention that, though there are no sources for this, it is a very squeezable-looking one.
Hmmm... Well, I would suggest "Kum," but such a name may be too similar to the term used for male orgasms... "Kuma," maybe?
Today is January 15. Can you guess why that is significant, ~player~? It is the birthday of Wikipedia!
Happy birthday, me! Wikipedia was launched on this day, January 15, back in 2001!
Today is my birthday! Wikipedia was launched on January 15, 2001. We should get some birthday cake to celebrate!
Are you not aware that you are famous, Asuna? Every action you take on the internet is documented and noticed by millions. The Knights of the Blood Oath are all very popular!
Mmh... It seems that there are no articles regarding the Augma. Could you explain to me what that is, Asuna?
Do you prefer bikinis or one-piece swimsuits, ~player~? If you want to see me in a one-piece, be sure to play my normal outfit.
Do you prefer bikinis or one-piece swimsuits, ~player~? If you want to see me in a bikini, be sure to play with me in the summer.

{b}"Airplanes"{!reset} is a 2010 song by American rapper B.o.B, featuring vocals from Hayley Williams, lead singer of American rock band Paramore. The song resurfaced in August 2021 when it was referenced in a viral TikTok featuring fanart made by user bluedog444 on deviantART in 2012.
Merry Christmas, ~player~! Or, if you do not celebrate Christmas, good day to you! Either way, do you think you could spare some money in the spirit of the holidays?
Oh? I see I am in good company among witches today! Well, as the Bard would put it, something wicked may indeed this way come!
Here is a fun fact: Team Magma's uniform socks are very itchy! Time to remove them like an unsourced article.
I suppose with so much of my cosplay removed, there is no point in keeping up the charade. You may return to calling me Wikipe-tan!

Did you know that the probability of drawing a four of a kind is 0.0240%?
Such a random, fun fact, right?

Here is a fun fact! The probability of drawing a full house is 0.1441% .
Which is actually higher than drawing a four of a kind!
Did you know that {b}Kazakhstan{!reset} covers a land area of 2,724,900 square kilometres (1,052,100 sq mi), and is the world's largest landlocked country, and the ninth-largest country in the world?

Did you know that {b}Kazakhstan{!reset} has a population of 18.8 million residents, and has one of the lowest population densities in the world, at fewer than 6 people per square kilometre (15 people per sq mi)?
I am sure you probably knew that {b}Kazakhstan{!reset} was the last of the Soviet republics to declare independence during the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991.

Although {b}Kazakhstan{!reset} is no longer part of the Soviet Union, it still leases approximately 6,000 sq km (2,317 sq mi) of land to Russia enclosing the Baikonur Cosmodrome space launch site, where Russia launches all of its crewed flights into space!
{b}Magma{!reset} comes from the Ancient Greek word μάγμα, or "thick unguent"!

In addition to the molten rock found under the Earth's surface, {b}magma{!reset} may also refer to characters in the manga series Dr. Stone, the anime Spider Riders, the film Gorath, and two separate Marvel Comics characters!
As they say in Pokémon, I "gotta catch 'em all," and I am not referring to sexually transmitted diseases!

In addition to the molten rock found under the Earth's surface, {b}magma{!reset} may also refer to an algebraic structure consisting of a set together with a binary operation, as well as the Magma computer algebra system, a software package for solving mathematical problems.
Did you know that {b}magma{!reset} is the molten or semi-molten natural material from which all igneous rocks are formed?
{b}Magma{!reset} is found beneath the surface of the Earth, but evidence of magma has also been discovered on other terrestrial planets and some natural satellites!

Magma is produced by melting of the mantle or the crust in various tectonic settings, which on Earth include subduction zones, continental rift zones, mid-ocean ridges, and hotspots. Besides molten rock, magma may also contain suspended crystals and gas bubbles.
{b}Lava{!reset} is different from magma, in that lava has been expelled from the interior of a planet (such as Earth) or a moon onto its surface.
I bet you did not know that {b}lava{!reset} can be erupted at a volcano or through a fracture in the crust, on land or undersea, usually at temperatures from 800 to 1,200 °C (1,470 to 2,190 °F)!
While a {b}lava flow{!reset} is an outpouring of lava during an effusive eruption, an explosive eruption produces a mixture of volcanic ash and other fragments called {b}tephra{!reset}.
Here is a fun fact! Most molten lava is about 10,000 to 100,000 times more viscous than water, with a viscosity roughly similar to ketchup. I would not advise eating it, though!

In addition to molten volcanic rock expelled from the Earth, {b}lava{!reset} may also refer to a 1980 Indian Malayalam action drama, a 1985 Indian Hindi drama, a 2001 British comedy, and a 2014 Pixar short film of the same name!
Say, ~player~, do you think you could donate? It takes a lot of money to keep Wikipe--erm, I mean to keep eco-terrorist organization Team Magma up and running!

A {b}slugma{!reset} is a generation II Pokémon. Also called a Magumaggu in Japanese, it appears as a slug made out of lava. When cooled, Slugma's body will turn brittle and break off, making it smaller.

The word lava comes from Italian and is probably derived from the Latin word labes, which means a fall or slide. Its first known use in connection with extrusion of magma from below the surface was in a short account of the 1737 eruption of Vesuvius written by Francesco Serao.

Have you ever had a {b}lava cake{!reset}, ~player~? It combines the elements of a chocolate cake and a soufflé. The dessert is known for its liquid molten chocolate center. I could go for one right about now...

A {b}vampire{!reset} is a creature from folklore that subsists by feeding on the vital essence (generally in the form of blood) of the living. Everything else changes depending on the culture and its folklore.

In law, an {b}alien{!reset} is any person (including an organization) who is not a citizen or a national of a specific country, although definitions and terminology differ to some degree depending upon the continent or region of Earth. More generally, however, the term "alien" is perceived as synonymous with foreign national.

A {b}catgirl{!reset} is a female kemonomimi character with cat traits, such as cat ears, a cat tail, or other feline characteristics on an otherwise human body. They are found in various fiction genres and in particular Japanese anime and manga.

A {b}demon{!reset} is a supernatural being, typically associated with evil. The original Greek word did not carry negative connotations, so it is safe to assume that they were added by medieval Christian demonology.

A {b}deity{!reset} or {b}god{!reset} is a supernatural being considered divine or sacred. It is often described as a being with powers greater than those of ordinary humans, but who interacts with humans, positively or negatively.
There must be an {b}adventurer{!reset} at this table! By definition, an adventurer is someone who seeks out adventures: exciting experiences that are typically bold, sometimes risky or undertaking.
{b}Angels{!reset} are supernatural beings in various religions often depicted as benevolent celestial intermediaries between God or Heaven and humanity, or protectors and guides for humans.
A {b}witch{!reset} is a practitioner of magical skills and abilities such as using spells, incantations and magical rituals. Any other exact details get blurred by cultural context.

A {b}superhero{!reset} is a stock character that possesses abilities beyond those of ordinary people, who typically uses their powers to help the world become a better place, protecting the public, and fighting crime.

Did you know about Pokéfuta? Also called "Poké Lids", these are manhole covers available in different cities in Japan that have been decorated with pictures of Pokémon. They serve as local points of interest for tourists and Pokémon Go players.

{b}Cute aggression{!reset} or {b}playful aggression{!reset} is superficially aggressive behaviour caused by seeing something cute, such as a human baby, a young animal or ~Moe~. People experiencing cute aggression may grit their teeth, clench their fists, or feel the urge to bite, pinch, and squeeze something they consider cute, while not actually causing or intending to cause any harm.
Have you been enjoying my knowledge this game, ~player~? If you have, can I humbly ask for a simple donation? Every penny counts!

It appears that someone has a fixation with maids, maid uniforms or serfdom in general. If that hypothetical someone would like for me to act as her maid, all they would have to do is name themselves as my "Master".

I must say... You are all quite skilled at this game, are you not? I would love to be as knowledgeable at this game as you are... Which is why I will humbly ask for a small donation to keep my main source of education free and available for everyone!
The form-fitting swimsuits we know of today would not appear until the 20th century, and even then would go through a significant amount of evolution.
... Being honest here, I did not actually come to the Inventory to research it. That would go against the NOR policy. I simply came here because of my own sexual curiosity.

Air (disambiguation). {b}Air{!reset} is part of the Earth's atmosphere that humans breathe. It is made up of 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, and 1% other (including water vapor). {b}Air{!reset} or {b}AIR{!reset} may also refer to:
{smaller}Air (Maillol), a sculpture by Aristide Maillol; Air (painting), a painting by Jan van Kessel the Elder; Air (video game), a 2000 Japanese visual novel; Air (2005 film), a 2005 anime adaptation of the visual novel; Air (band), a French electronic music duo; Air (free jazz trio), founded in 1971; Air (jazz rock band), a jazz rock group featuring Tom and Googie Coppola; Air, by Air (jazz rock band), 1971; Air (singer), Japanese singer; "Air" (Tyson Ritter song), 2013; "Air", a song by Ekseption from their self-titled 1969 album Ekseption, an adaptation of J.S. Bach music; "Air," a song by Brian Eno and Talking Heads from the 1979 album Fear of Music; "Air", a song by Ben Folds Five from the 1998 album Godzilla: The Album; "Air", a song by Shawn Mendes and Astrid S from Mendes's 2015 album Handwritten; "A.I.R.", a song by Anthrax from their 1985 album Spreading the Disease; Air (music), French for "aria," various song-like vocal or instrumental compositions; Air on the G String, August Wilhelmj's adaptation of an air by Johann Sebastian Bach; Art International Radio, an arts-oriented radio station; "Air" (Stargate Universe), the series premiere of the television series Stargate Universe; Air (1977 video game), an air combat based mainframe computer game; Air, a common colloquialism for a broadcast ("on air"); Air (comics), a comic book series published by the Vertigo imprint of DC Comics; AIR (nightclub), a 2000 capacity superclub located in Digbeth, Birmingham in the UK; Air (roller coaster), the former name of a flying roller coaster at Alton Towers theme park in the United Kingdom, now re-themed as "Galactica"; Annals of Improbable Research, a bi-monthly magazine devoted to scientific humour; AIR (program), a program suite for medical image registration; Adobe Integrated Runtime (Adobe AIR), a cross-platform run-time environment developed by Adobe Systems for building rich Internet applications; iPad Air, an Apple tablet; MacBook Air, an Apple ultraportable laptop; Air (classical element), an element in ancient Greek philosophy and in Western alchemy; Applied Innovative Research, a scientific journal; and another word for ambience (character, mood, etc.).
What do you mean that Henry Cavill is not dead? Do you have a source for that? I need to fix that article as soon as possible!

Remember to not believe everything you read on Wikipedia. On October 2012, the Asian Football Confederation was forced to apologize to the United Arab Emirates soccer team for referring to them as the "Sand Monkeys"; the spurious nickname had been taken from a vandalized Wikipedia article.

Did you know that Wikipedia has a Simple English edition? It is a very useful resource for ESL people, uneducated people or younger people. {smaller}(But if you are so young that you do not understand regular Wikipedia, you should not be playing this game!){!reset}

Part of my goal is to make Britannica-tan redundant.
{smaller}For legal reasons, this line {smaller b}contains material that is kept because it is considered humorous. {smaller}Such material is not meant to be taken seriously!{!reset}
Why, ~player~, do you consider yourself more of a Deletionist or an Inclusionist? You can be honest. Both stances have their positive merits, so I will not judge you.
While you can create an article about yourself, I advise you not to. Being objective about oneself is difficult, and your sources would be disputed, too.

Did you know that it is normal for music fandoms to compete with each other by reading Wikipedia articles of their respective bands for long amounts of time so they can rise in the ladder of engagement?

The {b}Seigenthaler incident{!reset} was a 2005 incident where an article falsely stated that journalist John Seigenthaler had been a suspect in the assassinations of U.S. President John F. Kennedy and U.S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy. Ever since then, unregistered users cannot create new articles.
Several articles were vandalized in such a humorous way that they were kept in a separate site to keep their creativity alive. Check bjaodn.org yourself to check it out!
I must not take notes of my speculations before the game is over... or else I will break TenPoundHammer's Law...
Even though I am an avid Wikipedian, I do not speak for Wikipedia as a whole. I would be breaking Shirt58's Law if I were to do so.
Have you ever woken up in the middle of the night with a very weird dream or wondering a random question? Wikipedia is always there to sate your midnight curiosity!
As much as it pains me to admit it, we have probably better articles on fictional stories than serious, real-life topics...
Have you checked our article on The Three Stooges? Some people have called it "a small book with everything you need to know about them" on its own.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you're talking with. For example, {b}-tan{!reset} is a way to refer to a very small child, or a moe anthropomorphism such as myself.
Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-chan{!reset} is used to refer to a small child or a young lady.
Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-san{!reset} is used to refer to an equal, similar to Mr. or Ms.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-sama{!reset} is used to refer to someone's highest superior, like a divine entity, a guest or a customer.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-kun{!reset} is informally used to refer to men in general, especially young boys.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-senpai{!reset} is used to refer to someone in a similar position as yours, but with more experience or knowledge.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-kouhai{!reset} is used to refer to someone in a similar position as yours, but who's more of a novice or generally inexperienced.

Japanese honorifics like my own -tan suffix are used to assign a certain connotation to the person you are talking to. For example, {b}-sensei{!reset} is used to refer to a teacher or someone in teaching authority.
Hello, Gordon!

Did you know that we are working on a Middle English version of Wikipedia? Here is a sample!
{small}A {small b}frogge{small} biþ a smal beaste wiþ foure leggys, whyche liueþ booþ in watyre and on londe. It is broune or grene or yelowe, or be it tropyckal, he may haue dyuers coloures. It haþ longys and guilles booþe. It haccheþ from an ey and it þan ys a tadpolle. It groweþ to ben a frogge, if it þan ne be noght eten.

Some people did not know this, but did you know that Strip Poker Night at the Inventory is loosely based on an earlier game, {b i}Poker Night at the Inventory{!reset}, which was developed by Telltale Games and released on November 22, 2010?

Did you know that the original {b i}Poker Night at the Inventory{!reset}, on which this game is based, featured four characters from different franchises: Tycho Brahe from the webcomic Penny Arcade, Max from Sam & Max, the Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Strong Bad from Homestar Runner?

I am glad you approve, Ms. Ardebit! People seem to respond positively to my swimsuit, perhaps due to its nature as {b}fan service{!reset}, material in a work of media that is intentionally added to please the audience.
Well, while I have the knowledge of many swimming techniques around the world, I cannot perform all of them. But yes, I have been told I am a good swimmer. Why do you ask?
It is my turn again? Great! Now I may educate you on another popular trope that emerged in later magical girl anime that was introduced in the 1990s!
Indeed I do! We have numerous articles about beaches, including a comprehensive list of Earth beaches and the eleven longest beaches on Earth. What would you like to hear, Miss Elden?

A {b}penis{!reset} (plural penises or penes) is the primary sexual organ that male animals use to inseminate females during copulation. Such organs occur in many animals, both vertebrate and invertebrate, but males do not bear a penis in every animal species.

{b}Dick's Sporting Goods, Inc.{!reset} is an American sporting goods retail company, based in Coraopolis, Pennsylvania. The company was established by Richard "Dick" Stack in 1948, and has approximately 854 stores and 50,100 employees. Dick's is America's largest sporting goods retailer.
Ms.... Grunt, was it? Or Ms. Magma? I am at your service. About what do you wish to enquire?

Well, Polly, a {b}meteorite{!reset} is a solid piece of debris from an object, such as a comet, asteroid, or meteoroid, that originates in outer space and survives its passage through the atmosphere to reach the surface of a planet or moon. When the original object enters the atmosphere, various factors such as friction, pressure, and chemical interactions with the atmospheric gases cause it to heat up and radiate energy. Only then does it become a meteor and form a fireball, also known as a shooting star or falling star. Once it settles on the larger body's surface, the meteor becomes a full meteorite. Otherwise, it might remain as a simple meteor and never turn into a full meteorite.
The -tan in my name is an affectionate suffix, in the form of a Japanese honorific. Like the OS-tan moe anthropomorphs of popular operating systems.
Thankfully, Miss Fluttershy, I myself do not manage Wikipedia. That said, having access to an ever-changing wealth of knowledge can be... intimidating.
Well, I can tell you that Wikipedia has 6.4 million articles in English and over 42 million contributors, and I can sense whenever new changes are made.

Have you tried engaging in {b}flirting{!reset}, Miss Fina? This refers to a social and sexual behavior involving spoken or written communication, as well as body language, by one person to another, to suggest interest in a deeper relationship with the other person.

Miss Heurassein, let me try to answer all of your questions. Yes, I am an administrator for {b}Wikipedia{!reset}, the free encyclopedia that anyone can edit! We have articles on science, history, language, literature, popular culture, anything! It can be accessed at en.wikipedia.org.

condition.saying: Wait, so you have a ton of knowledge on everything...

Curious... I work for {b}Wikipedia{!reset} and the {b}Wikimedia Foundation{!reset}, a nonprofit which is dedicated to spreading free and open-source information to the world. Do you not have that or some equivalent where you are from, Ms. Ardebit?
Why, anyone is allowed to contribute information! We have a large number of users and editors, although... well, information is required to be sourced, and we have no tolerance for vandals.
Ms. Setogaya, I have... what you might call a psychic connection with Wikipedia itself. I work for Wikipedia as an admin and a trusted editor, but I can also sense the edits as they're happening!

The {b}Internet{!reset} is the global system of interconnected computer networks that uses... right, how do I explain this to someone with no knowledge of computers... Okay, imagine communicating with people from other towns, from across the globe, but without leaving the comfort of your own home.

{b}Censorship of Wikipedia{!reset} has occurred in many countries, including China, France, Germany, Iran, Myanmar, Pakistan, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey, Uzbekistan, and Venezuela. I am not happy about it, but there is not a lot I can do about it.
Being an editor is a full-time committment, but whenever I get rare breaks, I like to swim, I sometimes take naps... oh, and as of recently, I have been coming to the Inventory.
Miss Sayori, you like to read poems, correct? Do you think it would be a good thing if everyone, everywhere, had access to read those poems?

I do write and edit articles, but I also server as Wikipedia's mascot, an administrator, and a spokesperson for the site! I attend conventions around the world as part of my job, and I enjoy that. There is nothing like seeing places in real life, even if you have information on them.

It appears that the cards have chosen me to strip this time. I hope you enjoy my performance, my ~player.ifMale(Lord|Lady)~.
Is it your wish for me to strip now, my ~player.ifMale(Lord|Lady)~? Very well.
If it is my ~player.ifMale(Lord|Lady)~'s wish for me to strip, then I shall do so.

I aim to please you. And if stripping my clothes is what it takes, then I shall strip them...

While I am pulling down my own swimsuit, I should point out that swimwear has a long and varied history. For example, did you know that in classical antiquity and in most cultures, swimming was usually done in the nude?
You are probably wondering "how did you get so good at this game, Ms. Wikipe-tan"? And the answer is very simple.

I should commend you on your skills. But since this poker variant is mostly based on chance, that statement would require more accurate sources.
Nothing to worry about. I am still in the lead, after all.
I still have the advantage, so I can spare some clothing.

I could teach you how to play better... But you would not grow. You would not improve. You would merely take a shortcut and gain nothing. You would experience a hollow victory, where nothing was risked and nothing was gained.
No problem. Even if you vandalized this hand, I would have won anyway.
You need to learn to change your hands better, like I edit my articles for perfection.
I do not think removing my shoes is interesting at all, so I will proceed to tell you all about one of my most treasured childhood movies.
No problem, it was about time for me to strip some more.
Thirsty for more? I can spare more clothing. I am in the lead after all.

Well... It is a game of chance after all. Not all rounds can be won.
Good plays, everyone. Allow me to recompense your efforts.

I believe this is one of the reasons people prefer this poker variant. The increased importance of luck makes all rounds unpredictable, while every layer lost makes every round spicier than the one before...
Well, here goes nothing...
Sure, I will do it. At least I am not losing as bad as others here.

Not exactly what I expected, but I still have a chance to recover from this.
I have to step up my game. Not that I am doing badly, but you never know when the odds might turn against you.
I should have expected it with such a hand...

Good plays, everyone. Allow me to recompense your efforts.
I was sure I was at least decent at this game... Looks like I did not read enough articles on the matter.
Am I playing badly? Did I misunderstand the articles on poker strategies?

I will strip, but... I should be playing better. I thought I was a better player than this. That upsets me.

I should not be surprised that you are trying your hardest to see more of me. Just like people can not get enough of Wikipedia's articles.

A casual setting like this may be a good venue to practice. Social etiquette generally disapproves of a direct expression of sexual interest, but strip poker has a more fun and light social atmosphere.

WIKI POWER!
To give citations to those in need, to spread knowledge for the curious, and to stop vandals in their pursuit of ignorance. I strike at thee, with the blessings of my... WIKI POWER!

In {b}human reproduction{!reset}, the man typically inserts his penis, which needs to be erect, into the female's vagina, and then either partner initiates rhythmic pelvic thrusts until the male ejaculates semen, which contains sperm, into the vaginal canal. This process is also known as "coitus," "mating," "having sex," or, euphemistically, "making love."
I... fail to understand what you are talking about, Miss Elden. We have no such organ-harvesting programs... is this a multiverse thing?

{b}Penile erection{!reset} is the result of a complex interaction of psychological, neural, vascular, and endocrine factors, and is often associated with sexual arousal or sexual attraction, although erections can also be spontaneous.
Actually, human standards of beauty have changed notably within the past two centuries, and has come to include {b}sapiosexuality{!reset}, a subcategory of attraction based on intelligence!

You may be amused, but it is merely part of natural reproductive processes for all mammalian species! In most species of animals in which there is an organ that might reasonably be described as a penis, it has no major function other than conveying the sperm to the female.

Obviously, there are certain things that we may never know. The meaning of life, for example, has a lot of words, but no definitive answer. Like most politicians!
Wha... Jim, I am surprised in you. A-and furthermore, do you have any sources to back up such a hefty claim?

{b}Lascivious behavior{!reset} is sexual behavior or conduct that is considered crude and offensive, or contrary to local moral or other standards of appropriate behavior. In this sense, "lascivious" is similar in meaning to "lewd," "indecent," "lecherous," "unchaste," "licentious," or "libidinous."

{b}Indecent exposure{!reset} is an expression that describes the deliberate public exposure by a person of a portion of their body in a manner contrary to local standards of appropriate behavior. Laws and social attitudes regarding indecent exposure vary significantly in different countries.

{b}Lust{!reset} is a psychological force producing intense desire for an object, or circumstance while already having a significant other or amount of the desired object. Lust can take any form such as the lust for sexuality (see libido), food (see gluttony), money, or power.

{b}Mooning{!reset} is the act of displaying one's bare buttocks by removing clothing, e.g., by lowering the backside of one's trousers and underpants, usually bending over, and also potentially exposing the genitals. Mooning is used in the English-speaking world to express protest, scorn, disrespect, or for provocation, but mooning can be done for shock value, for fun, as a joke or as a form of exhibitionism.

{b}Sexual intercourse{!reset} (or {b}coitus{!reset} or {b}copulation{!reset}) is a sexual activity typically involving the insertion and thrusting of the penis into the vagina for sexual pleasure, reproduction, or both. This is also known as {b}vaginal intercourse{!reset} or {b}vaginal sex{!reset}.

{b}Sexual intercourse{!reset} takes various forms, include anal sex (penetration of the anus by the penis), oral sex (penetration of the mouth by the penis or oral penetration of the female genitalia), fingering (sexual penetration by the fingers) and penetration by use of a dildo (especially a strap-on dildo).

{b}Fingering{!reset} is typically the use of fingers or hands to sexually stimulate the vulva (including the clitoris) or vagina. Fingering may be performed on oneself (masturbation) or by or with a sexual partner. When performed on the vulva or vagina by a sexual partner, it is a form of mutual masturbation, and is analogous to a handjob (the manual stimulation of the penis).

{b}Oral sex{!reset}, sometimes referred to as {b}oral intercourse{!reset}, is sexual activity involving the stimulation of the genitalia of a person by another person using the mouth (including the lips, tongue, or teeth) and the throat. Cunnilingus is oral sex performed on the vulva or vagina, while fellatio is oral sex performed on the penis.

A {b}butte{!reset} is an isolated hill with steep sides and a flat top. {b}Butte{!reset} may also refer to: Butte, Alaska; Butte, Montana; Butte Mountains, Nevada; Butte, Nebraska; Butte, North Dakota; and Butte City, California.

I believe you and I must be kindred spirits in the quest for knowledge, Sucrose!
{small}Not to be confused with the adult yuri visual novel Kindred Spirits on the Roof, from 2012.
I... I already told you I am not a ghost. But I can tell you that according to a 2009 study by the Pew Research Center, 18% of Americans say they have seen a ghost.

I... I already told you I am not a ghost. But while we are on the subject, did you know that common prescription medication and over-the-counter drugs, such as sleeping aids, may in rare instances cause ghost-like hallucinations, as does carbon monoxide poisoning?
Indeed! Some Japanese folktales speak of kitsune as faithful guardians, friends, and lovers. But there is no need to feel envious of me, Senko-san!

An {b}encyclopedia{!reset}, {b}encyclopædia{!reset}, or {b}encyclopaedia{!reset} is a reference work or compendium providing summaries of knowledge either from all branches or from a particular field or discipline. Encyclopedias are divided into articles that are often arranged alphabetically by article name and sometimes by thematic categories.

An {b}encyclopedia{!reset}, {b}encyclopædia{!reset}, or {b}encyclopaedia{!reset} is a reference work or compendium providing summaries of knowledge either from all branches or from a particular field or discipline. Encyclopedias have existed for around 2,000 years and can be found online or in book form.

Well, Wikipedia knows way more than one thousand things. In fact, we currently have 6.4 million articles and counting about many subjects relevant to our world, including science, history, philosophy, music, and many subsets of popular culture, all free to access and added by our beloved contributors!

Ah yes, Fina, you must be referring to {b}homosexuality{!reset}! We have many articles on the subject, including sex practices, which often include the use of oral sex (fellatio for men, cunnilingus for women), as well as anal penetration for men (sodomy) and the use of toys such as strap-on dildos for women.

Ah, Fina, you must be referring to {b}bondage{!reset}, the practice of consensually tying, binding, or restraining a partner for erotic, aesthetic, or somatosensory stimulation. It is not widely accepted, but it is definitely more mainstream now than it has been in the past.

Oh! So you want to know about {b}group sex{!reset}, sexual behavior involving more than two participants simultaneously? Any form of sexual activity can be adopted to involve more than two participants. There are {b}threesomes{!reset}, with three participants; {b}foursomes{!reset}, with four; and {b}orgies{!reset}, with five or more.

The effects of the consumption of alcohol on sexual behavior are widely detailed, Ms. Fina. Alcohol is a depressant, and balance, judgment, and coordination can be negatively affected by it. Whatever you do, consent is key to a good sexual experience!

Ah, I see. So you are interested in {b}polyamory{!reset}, the practice of, or desire for, intimate relationships with more than one partner, with the informed consent of all partners involved? This is not to be confused with {b}group sex{!reset}, having sex with multiple partners at once, although that can be involved.

Earth's human population passed seven billion in the early 2010s. Human population density varies widely around the world, but a majority live in Asia. By 2050, 68% of the world's population is expected to be living in urban, rather than rural, areas.

Cosplayers often interact to create a subculture, and a broader use of the term "cosplay" applies to any costumed role-playing in venues apart from the stage.

Cosplay grew out of the practice of fan costuming at science fiction conventions, beginning with Morojo's "futuristicostumes" created for the 1st World Science Fiction Convention held in New York City in 1939.

The Japanese term "cosplay" (kosupure) was coined in 1984, and a rapid growth in the number of people cosplaying as a hobby since the 1990s has made the phenomenon a significant aspect of popular culture in Japan, as well as in other parts of East Asia and in the Western world.
While cosplay is not as accepted in America as it is in Japan, it is still enjoyed in the States as a key aspect of the popular holiday Halloween.
Cosplay costumes vary greatly and can range from simple themed clothing to highly detailed costumes. For my own cosplay, I included specially themed underwear to match!
Even I have cosplayed before! If you catch me around Halloween, you are likely to find me dressed as a majokko, or "little witch," the predecessor to the magical girl shows of today.

What Zoe is referencing here is a reference to "{b}Loss{!reset}," a strip published on June 2, 2008, by Tim Buckley for his gaming-related webcomic Ctrl+Alt+Del. Set during a storyline in which the main character Ethan and his fiancée Lilah are expecting their first child, the strip—presented as a four-panel comic with no dialogue—shows Ethan entering a hospital, where he sees Lilah weeping in a hospital bed: she has suffered a miscarriage. Buckley cited events in his life as inspiration for the comic. It has received negative reception from critics and webcomic creators, especially for the shift in tone in the webcomic, and later garnered a legacy as an internet meme, with other creators making edits and minimalistic versions of the strip.

What Zoe is referencing here is {b}The Game{!reset}, a mental game where the objective is to avoid thinking about The Game itself. Thinking about The Game constitutes a loss, which must be announced each time it occurs. It is impossible to win most versions of The Game. Depending on the variation of The Game, the whole world, or all those aware of the game, are playing it all the time.

What Zoe is referencing here is {b i}The Dress{!reset}, a photograph that became a viral phenomenon on the Internet in 2015. Viewers of the image disagreed on whether the dress depicted was colored black and blue, or white and gold. The phenomenon originated from a washed-out color photograph of a dress posted on Facebook. Within a week, more than ten million tweets had mentioned the dress, using hashtags such as #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue. Although the dress was eventually confirmed to be black and blue, the image prompted much online discussion of different users' perceptions of the color of the dress.

{b}War paint{!reset} is paint ritually applied to the face and/or body prior to going into a battle. It may also refer to Warpaint, a 2008 album by the Black Crowes.

{b}Military camouflage{!reset} is the use of camouflage by an armed force to protect personnel and equipment from observation by enemy forces. The French slang word camouflage came into common English usage during World War I when the concept of visual deception developed into an essential part of modern military tactics.

{b i}Commando{!reset} is a 1985 American action film directed by Mark L. Lester and starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Rae Dawn Chong, and Alyssa Milano. The term "commando" also refers to the act of going commando, or to go without underwear.

In medicine, a {b}prosthesis{!reset} or {b}prosthetic implant{!reset} is an artificial device that replaces a missing body part, which may be lost through trauma, disease, or a condition present at birth (congenital disorder).

A {b}bandage{!reset} is a piece of material used either to support a medical device such as a dressing or splint, or on its own to provide support to or to restrict the movement of a part of the body.

A bandana can be worn around the mouth and nose to protect from dust inhalation or to hide the identity of its wearer.
Bandanas can be worn around the neck to prevent sunburn. I often use them when going to the beach.

The term "bikini" was coined by French automobile and fashion designer Louis Réard in July 1946. Réard named the swimsuit after Bikini Atoll, where testing on the new atomic bomb was occurring that summer.

Louis Réard termed the swimsuit "bikini" after the American nuclear testing site at Bikini Atoll because he believed its revealing style would create reactions among people similar to those created by America’s atomic bomb in Japan just one summer earlier.

The bikini is often worn in hot weather, while swimming or sunbathing. The design became common in Western countries by the mid 1960s as both swimwear and underwear. By the late 20th century, it was widely used as sportswear in beach volleyball and bodybuilding.

Due to its revealing design, the bikini was considered controversial and was banned in many countries; however, it gained exposure and acceptance as film stars like Brigitte Bardot, Raquel Welch, and Ursula Andress wore them.

One of the basic pieces of furniture, a {b}chair{!reset} is a type of seat. Its primary features are two pieces of a durable material, attached as back and seat to one another at a 90° or slightly greater angle.

Used in a number of rooms in homes, in schools and offices, and in various other workplaces, {b}chairs{!reset} may be made of wood, metal, or synthetic materials, and either the seat alone or the entire chair may be padded or upholstered in various colors and fabrics.

{b}Chairs{!reset} vary in design. An {b}armchair{!reset} has armrests fixed to the seat; a {b}recliner{!reset} is upholstered and has a mechanism that allows one to lower the chair's back and raise into place a fold-out footrest; a {b}rocking chair{!reset} has legs fixed to two long curved slats; and a {b}wheelchair{!reset} has wheels fixed to an axis under the seat.

On this day in 1911, the technology company IBM was founded as the {b}Computing- Tabulating-Recording Company{!reset} in Endicott, New York. Isn't that interesting, ~player~?
Today was the birthday of American rapper Tupac Shakur in 1971! Want to listen to some of his music with me after the game is over, ~player~?

Boy, that was sure some ride I went on... But not as much of a ride as the first purpose-built roller coaster, LaMarcus Adna Thompson's {b}"Switchback Railway,"{!reset} which opened in New York's Coney Island amusement park on this day in 1886!
On this day in 1902, the {b}Ford Motor Company{!reset} was incorporated. Henry Ford was once quoted as saying the early Ford models could be "any color, so long as it's black"!
On this day in 1963, cosmonaut {b}Valentina Tereshkova{!reset} became the first woman in space on Vostok 6! I hope I can go to space some day...
In Argentina, this day is celebrated as {b}Engineer's Day{!reset}! We would truly not go far without our engineers!
On this day in 1972, David Bowie released {b}The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars,{!reset} debuting his character, the androgynous alien rockstar Ziggy Stardust!
The {b}Monterey Pop Festival{!reset} began at the Monterey Fairgrounds in California on this day in 1967. The festival was documented in the 1968 film, Monterey Pop.
The film adaptation of {b}Grease{!reset} premiered in New York City on this day in 1978. And still to this day, nobody knows what "ramma lamma lamma ka dinga da dinga dong" means...
The {b}New York Jazz Museum{!reset} opened on this day in 1972. Ya like jazz, ~player~?
On this day in 1999, {b}Phil Collins{!reset} received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. {b}Da-dun, da-dun, da-dun, da-dun, dun dun!
Disney's classic animated film, {b}Lilo & Stitch,{!reset} was released on this day in 2002! I am somewhat surprised Nani has never played this game with us...

Did you know that on this day in 1885, the {b}Statue of Liberty{!reset} arrived in New York Harbor? Although it would not be formally opened until October 28, 1886, and would not gain its distinctive green color until 1900-1906.
On this day in 1901, the {b}College Board{!reset} introduced its first standardized test, the forerunner to the SAT which would cause suffering among American students everywhere!
Did you know that composer {b}Igor Stravinsky{!reset} was born on this day in 1882? His ballet, The Rite of Spring, allegedly sent crowds into a frenzy during its early run!

{b}Gregg Rolie{!reset}, the keyboardist and singer of Santana and founder of Journey, was born on this day in 1947!
Any way you want it, that's the way you need it!
American rapper {b}Kendrick Lamar{!reset} (drank) was born (drank) on this day (drank) in 1987 (drank)... HEY! DID SOMEBODY VANDALIZE THAT?!
On this day in 1980, {b}Led Zeppelin{!reset} began what would be their last tour.
{b}Rod Stewart{!reset} set an attendance record for Wembley Stadium with a concert crowd of 90,000 on this day in 1995. That's over two football fiel--wait...
Today is {b}Autistic Pride Day{!reset}, ~player~! This day recognises the importance of pride for autistic people and its role in bringing about positive changes in the broader society.

On this day in 1858, {b}Charles Darwin{!reset} received a manuscript by fellow naturalist Alfred Russel Wallace on natural selection, which encouraged Darwin to publish his theory of evolution. What do you think, ~player~? Have we gone too far? Should we return to monkë?
On this day in 1928, aviator {b}Amelia Earhart{!reset} became the first woman to fly in an aircraft across the Atlantic Ocean! As an aeronautical radio operator myself, I find this fascinating.

On this day in 1948, Columbia Records introduced the {b}long-playing record album{!reset}, or {b}LP{!reset}, at a public demonstration at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City. If you like music, ~player~, then this was important in the development of your music-listening.
Why don't we do it in the road, ~player~? Today in 1942 was singer-songwriter Paul McCartney's birthday!

On this day in 1967, the Jimi Hendrix Experience made its debut performance at the {b}Monterey Pop Festival{!reset} in California. Their electrifying performance, including Jimi famously lighting his guitar on fire, was documented in the 1968 film Monterey Pop.

Happy {b}Juneteenth{!reset}, ~player~! This day is commemorated on the anniversary date of the June 19, 1865 announcement of Union Army general Gordon Granger, proclaiming freedom from slavery in Texas.

The comic {b}Garfield,{!reset} created by Jim Davis, debuted in American newspapers nationwide on this day in 1978. While the comic is still being made to this day, Jim Davis's continued involvement is disputed. {smaller}[citation needed]
On this day in 1910, the first {b}Father's Day{!reset} was celebrated in Spokane, Washington. Of course, in a sexual context, "daddy" has a much different meaning.
Although I derived pleasure from this game, some people need more adrenaline to get a kick, which is why the first ever {b}NASCAR{!reset} race was held at Charlotte Speedway on this day in 1949.
The first officially recorded, organized {b}baseball{!reset} game was played in Hoboken, New Jersey's Elysian Fields on this day in 1846.
Today in 1950 was the birthday of {b}Ann Wilson{!reset}, the lead singer and co-founder of American rock band Heart! Do you like any of their music, ~player~?

Over 3,000 East Germans gathered at the Berlin Wall to hear {b}Michael Jackson{!reset}, who was performing a concert on the other side of the wall in West Berlin on this day in 1988. Truly, music does bring us together!
Pixar's animated film {b}Inside Out{!reset} was released on this day in 2015... and no, it never made me cry! Sh-shut up! {small}[citation needed]

The DC superhero film {b}Batman Returns{!reset} was released on this day in 1992. It was not as successful as the first movie, perhaps because it was a movie that was set at Christmas but released in the summer.
Steve Martin's romantic comedy film {b}Roxanne{!reset} was released on this day in 1987! Did you know that it is a modern retelling of Edmond Rostand's 1897 verse play Cyrano de Bergerac?

On this day in 1975, the film {b}Jaws{!reset} was released in the United States, becoming the highest-grossing film of that time and starting the trend of films known as "summer blockbusters." Cool, right?
On this day in 2003, the Wikimedia Foundation was founded in St. Petersburg, Florida. So you know what that means, player... *shakes cup*
On this day in 1877, {b}Alexander Graham Bell{!reset} installed the world's first commercial telephone service in Hamilton, Ontario. I wonder if he knew that telephones would take over our lives...
Hello? Is it Wikipedia you're looking for? American singer and musician {b}Lionel Richie{!reset} was born on this day in 1949.
Happy birthday to American voice actress {b}Tress MacNeille{!reset}! The zany-to-the-max voice of Dot from Animaniacs was born on this day in 1951.
Today in 1950 was the birthday of {b}Ann Wilson{!reset}, the lead singer and co-founder of American rock band Heart! Do you like any of their music, ~player~?

The Beatles' album, {b}Yesterday & Today,{!reset} was released by Capitol Records on this day in 1966... and almost immediately had to be repackaged when the original cover art was deemed unsuitable for American record stores.
The superhero movie {b}Batman and Robin{!reset} was released on this day in 1997. So come on, ~player~... chill.
John Landis' comedy film The Blues Brothers was released on this day in 1980. It was one of the most expensive comedies ever produced!
On this day in 1976, at the Olympic Games in 1976, {b}Nadia Comăneci{!reset} became the first person to score a perfect 10 in a modern Olympics gymnastics event.

This day in 1921 saw the birthday of American astronaut {b}John Glenn{!reset}! In 1962, Glenn was the first American to orbit the Earth, and in 1998, he went to space again at age 77, making him the oldest person in space!

This day in 1869 was the birthday of German zoologist {b}Maria von Linden{!reset}, known for her scientific investigations on butterfly wings and for being one of the first women in Germany given the title of "professor"!
In Brussels, {b}Prince Charles I{!reset} was crowned Duke of Burgundy and Count of Flanders on this day in 1507.
On this day in 1841, {b}Pedro II{!reset} was coronated as the second--and ultimately last--Emperor of Brazil, as he would be overthrown in a coup d'état in 1889.
On this day in 1862, T. S. Kennedy became the first person to ascend {b}Dent Blanche{!reset}, one of the highest summits in the Alps. Have you ever climbed a mountain, ~player~?
On this day in 1966, {b}Gemini 10{!reset} was launched from Cape Canaveral on a 70-hour mission that included one of the first space dockings!
Today was the birthday of American marshal {b}Virgil Earp{!reset} in 1843, whom you may be aware of from the 1993 film Tombstone, which depicted the Earps' famous Gunfight at the O.K. Corral.
Today was the birthday of {b}Machine Gun Kelly{!reset}, who... no, not that Machine Gun Kelly! I mean the American gangster of the same name, who was born on this day in 1895.
This day in 1929 was the birthday of {b}Screamin' Jay Hawkins{!reset}, known by some as the original shock rocker. ♫ I put a spell on you... because you're mine. ♫

Today in 1937 was the birthday of {b}Hunter S. Thompson{!reset}, the Gonzo journalist known for the novel Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas. You know, ~player~, they say that he who makes a beast out of himself gets rid of the pain of being a man.
Today in 1938 was the birthday of {b}Ian Stewart{!reset}, the original keyboardist and long-time road manager of the Rolling Stones!

This day in 1938 was the birthday of Dutch film director {b}Paul Verhoeven{!reset}, who you either know for his work on such beloved films as RoboCop, Total Recall, and Starship Troopers, or for... Showgirls. Enough said.
Today in 1950 was the birthday of billionaire {b}Richard Branson{!reset}, originally known as the founder of Virgin Records, but currently known for a weird space race with Jeff Bezos.

Today is {b}Nelson Mandela International Day{!reset}, ~player~! Dedicated to South African revolutionary and president Nelson Mandela--although according to some, Mandela died in prison in the 1980s (see also: the Mandela Effect), this fact is untrue.
American psychedelic rock band the Grateful Dead released their influential second album, {b}Anthem of the Sun,{!reset} on this day in 1968.

On this day in 1995, the {b}oldest known musical instrument{!reset} in the world was found in the Indrijca River Valley in Slovenia. The 45,000 year-old relic was a bear bone with four artificial holes along its length.
Christopher Nolan's acclaimed superhero movie The Dark Knight was first released on this day in 2008.
On this day in 2013, the NASA spacecraft Cassini took a photograph of Saturn with Earth in the distance, titled {b}The Day the Earth Smiled,{!reset} for which people were invited to "wave at Saturn."
The {b}British Medical Association{!reset} was founded as the Provincial Medical and Surgical Association by Sir Charles Hastings on this day in 1832.

Isambard Kingdom Brunel's steamship the {b}SS Great Britain{!reset} was launched on this day in 1843. It became the first ocean-going craft with an iron hull and screw propeller, and at the time was the longest passenger ship in the world.
The {b}Seneca Falls Convention{!reset}, the first women's rights convention, was held in the Wesleyan Chapel of the town of Seneca Falls, New York starting on this day in 1848.
On this day in 1900, the first line of the {b}Paris Métro{!reset} opened for operation.
On this day in 1903, Maurice Garin won the {b}first Tour de France{!reset}. Do you like to bicycle, ~player~?

On this day in 1977, the world's first {b}Global Positioning System{!reset} (GPS) signal was transmitted from Navigation Technology Satellite 2 (NTS-2). So amazing that such technology is now a common part of our travels nowadays...

On this day in 1980, the {b}1980 Summer Olympics{!reset} opened in Moscow. These games were most famous for the United States not participating in the Olympics for the first time, in a boycott against the then-Soviet Union.

Today in 1883 was the birthday of {b}Max Fleischer{!reset}, the Austrian-American animator known for bringing characters such as Betty Boop, Popeye, and Superman to the movie screen, and for developing animation techniques like Rotoscoping.

This day in 1947 was the birthday of {b}Bernie Leadon{!reset}, the original lead guitarist for the Eagles who played on songs like "One of These Nights." Speaking of which, ~player~, I hope you will play against me again one of these nights.
Happy birthday, {b}Brian May{!reset}! The famed astrophysicist and lead guitarist of Queen was born on this day in 1947.
{b}Keith Godchaux{!reset}, the third keyboardist for the Grateful Dead, was born on this day in 1947. He served with the band from 1971-1979 before being replaced by Brent Mydland.

British rock band {b}Deep Purple{!reset} broke up on this day in 1976. Of course, they would reform less than a decade later--and a bogus version of the band would tour even earlier in 1981! (See also: Bogus Deep Purple)
The movie Clueless was released on this day in 1995, and... I am pretty clueless as to what else I should say about it, so... let's move on!

Today is quite the day for history, ~player~. On this day in 1969, during the {b}Apollo 11{!reset} mission, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to land on the Moon, landing in the lunar Sea of Tranquility.

On this day in 1793, Scottish explorer {b}Alexander Mackenzie{!reset} reached the Pacific coast at Bella Coola, British Columbia, completing the first recorded transcontinental crossing of North America north of Mexico.

After being fully restored, the {b}USS Constitution,{!reset} one of the original six frigates of the United States Navy, celebrated its 200th birthday by sailing for the first time in 116 years on this day in 1997. She is the world's oldest ship of any type still afloat.
On this day in 1903, the {b}Ford Motor Company{!reset} shipped its first automobile.
On this day in 1976, the American {b}Viking 1{!reset} lander successfully landed on Mars. It was the first successful Mars lander in history and was operational for over 6¼ years.
On this day in 2005, the Civil Marriage Act legalized same-sex marriage in Canada.
Early Italian Renaissance cholar and poet Francesco Petrarca, better known as {b}Petrarchx{!reset}, was born on this day in 1304.

Austro-German geneticist {b}Gregor Mendel{!reset} was born on this day in 1822. He Mendel coined the terms "recessive" and "dominant" in reference to genetic traits, years before "dominant" took on a different context.
Today in 1933 was the birthday of novelist {b}Cormac McCarthy{!reset}, best known for his novels No Country for Old Men and The Road.

This day in 1938 was the birthday of Dame {b}Diana Rigg{!reset}, an English actress best known for her role in The Avengers... no, not that Avengers, ~player~! The British spy TV show of the same name!
Happy birthday, {b}Carlos Santana{!reset}! The Mexican-American guitarist known for his blending of rock, jazz, and Latin sounds was born on this day in 1947.
Never mind the bollocks--today was the birthday of {b}Paul Cook{!reset}, drummer and founding member of the pioneering punk band, the Sex Pistols!
Today is a big day in grunge rock: it marks the birthday of Soundgarden and Audioslave lead singer {b}Chris Cornell{!reset} in 1964, and Pearl Jam guitarist {b}Stone Gossard{!reset} in 1966!

Today is {b}International Chess Day{!reset}, ~player~!
...Hmm. Now there's an idea: Strip Chess Night at the Inventory.
American magazine Billboard published its first listing of best-selling singles on this day in 1940, the predecessor to their Billboard Hot 100.

British rock band Electric Light Orchestra dedicated their single {b}"Don't Bring Me Down"{!reset} to American space station Skylab on this day in 1979. The station had burned up upon reentry into the Earth's atmosphere nine days earlier.
On this day in 1965, {b}Bob Dylan{!reset} released the single "Like a Rolling Stone" from his album Highway 61 Revisited. It would become Dylan's highest charting single.
Today in 1984 saw the release of Revenge of the Nerds. Hmm. Funny, I thought that was just an alternate title for this game.
On this day in 2001, Studio Ghibli released Spirited Away, directed by Hayao Miyazaki! What's your favorite Ghibli film, ~player~?
On this day in 1983, Madonna released her {b}self-titled debut album{!reset}, which, while it sold slowly at first, would set the standard for the genre of dance-pop for decades.
Bet you didn't know that on this day in 1549, Jesuit priest {b}Francis Xavier{!reset} became the first missionary to travel by ship to Japan.
On this day in 1794, {b}Maximilien Robespierre{!reset} was arrested after encouraging the execution of more than 17,000 during the French Revolution. You could make a religion out of this!

The first permanent {b}transatlantic telegraph cable{!reset} was completed on this day in 1866. It stretched from Valentia Island, Ireland, to Heart's Content, Newfoundland pushed the boundaries for communication.
This day in 1940 saw the first introduction of {b}Bugs Bunny{!reset}! He debuted in the Tex Avery animated short A Wild Hare

American philanthropist {b}Elizabeth Plankinton{!reset} was born on this day in 1853. She was also known as "Miss Lizzie" and the people of Milwaukee called her the "municipal patroness" because of her generosity.
Today in 1922 was the birthday of American screenwriter and producer {b}Norman Lear{!reset}! He was known for producing sitcoms such as All in the Family, Maude, The Jeffersons, and Good Times!
Stevie Nicks's first solo album, {b}Bella Donna,{!reset} was released on this day in 1981. We're still awaiting word on whether Tom Petty stopped dragging her heart around.
Prince's first movie, {b}Purple Rain,{!reset} was released in the US on this day in 1984. It would go on to gross $70.3 million and have a platinum-selling soundtrack album.

On this day in 1984, Metallica's sophomore album, {b}Ride the Lightning,{!reset} was released. Although 75,000 copies were initially pressed for the American market, the album sold half a million by November 1987. It would eventually be certified 6× platinum and would be rated as one of the greatest albums of all time.

Did you know that on this day in 1986, {b}Queen{!reset} became the first act since Louis Armstrong to play in then-Soviet controlled Budapest, Hungary? Their performance would be documented in the concert film Hungarian Rhapsody.
On this day in 1866, {b}Vinnie Ream{!reset} became the first and youngest female artist to receive a commission from the United States government for a statue (of Abraham Lincoln) at the age of 18.
On this day in 1868, the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution was certified, establishing African American citizenship!

On this day in 1914, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia, which somehow wound up getting every other country involved and igniting {b}World War I....
{!reset} Look, I may be super knowledgeable, but even I can't make sense of that.

On this day in 1984, the {b}1984 Summer Olympic Games{!reset} were opened in Los Angeles! Although not every country participated, with several countries in Eastern Europe, most notably the Soviet Union, boycotting the games.

Nearly 600,000 people attended the {b}Summer Jam at Watkins Glen{!reset} rock festival at the Watkins Glen International Raceway on this day in 1973. Co-headlined by the Allman Brothers Band, Grateful Dead and The Band, it once received the Guinness Book of World Records entry for "Largest audience at a pop festival."
The remains of a prehistoric man are discovered near Kennewick, Washington on this day in 1996. These remains would become known as the {b}Kennewick Man.
Today was the birthday of American polka musician {b}Frankie Yankovic{!reset} in 1915! Surprisingly enough, he has no relation to fellow accordionist "Weird Al" Yankovic.
This day in 1916 was the birthday of {b}David Brown{!reset}, the film producer of blockbuster movies such as Jaws and Cocoon.

This day in 1943 was the birthday of American guitarist {b}Mike Bloomfield{!reset}, best known for his work on Bob Dylan's Highway 61 Revisited and in Dylan's infamous electric performance at the Newport Folk Festival in 1965.
Happy birthday to {b}Richard "Rick" Wright! The founding keyboardist of Pink Floyd who contributed to all but one of their album was born on this day in 1943.

{b}Jim Davis{!reset}, the American cartoonist who created Garfield, was born on this day in 1945. Although he has not actually written or drawn for Garfield since the late 1990s.{smaller}[citation needed]
{b}Simon Kirke{!reset}, the founding drummer of Free and Bad Company, was born on this day in 1949.
This day in 1990 was the birthday of American rapper {smaller}[citation needed]{!reset} and game console developer {smaller}[citation needed] {b}Soulja Boy{!reset}.

On this day in 1987, the Beatles famously sued Nike and Capitol Records over the use of their song {b}"Revolution"{!reset} in shoe commercials. Because there is no better way of staging a revolution than advertising for a shoe company.

This day in 2017 saw the release of Sony Pictures Animation's film {b}The Emoji Movie,{!reset} which has frequently been cited as one of the world films of all time yet still grossed $217.8 million. Money that could have been donated to Wikipedia instead...
The {b}Cape Cod Canal{!reset}, which connects Cape Cod Bay and Buzzards Bay in the state of Massachusetts, opened on a limited basis on this day in 1914.
Bet you didn't know that on this day in 1954, {b}The Fellowship of the Ring,{!reset} the first book in J. R. R. Tolkien's high-fantasy novel The Lord of the Rings, was published!

The {b}wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer{!reset} took place on this day in 1981. It was one of the first widely televised weddings, with an estimated 750 million people watching the ceremony worldwide.
The Connecticut Valley Railroad opened between Old Saybrook, Connecticut and Hartford, Connecticut in the U.S. on this day in 1871.
The {b}BBC Light Programme{!reset} radio station was launched for mainstream light entertainment and music on this day in 1945. It would operate until 1967, when it was replaced by BBC Radio 1 and 2.

The {b}1948 Summer Olympics{!reset} began in London on this day in 1948. After a hiatus of 12 years caused by World War II, these were the first Summer Olympics to be held since the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin.
This day in 1957 saw the premiere of {b}The Jack Paar Tonight Show{!reset} on NBC! It would prove popular and influential on modern nighttime talk shows.
On this day in 1958, the {b}National Aeronautics and Space Act{!reset} was signed into law, which created the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)!

On this day in 2005, astronomers announced the discovery of {b}Eris{!reset}, originally considered the tenth planet in the Solar System. This designation would eventually lead to the creation of the "dwarf planet" designation, which would prove controversial as Pluto would no longer be considered a planet.
"Living in the limelight, the universal dream," or at least for {b}Geddy Lee{!reset}, the lead singer and bassist of Canadian progressive rock band Rush, who was born on this day in 1953!

{b}John Sykes{!reset}, the British guitarist best known for his tenure in Thin Lizzy and Whitesnake, was born on this day in 1954!
{smaller}Not to be confused with John Sykes, the co-founder of MTV.

Perhaps you are tired of my daily facts and would like me to shut up. "Shut up" was a comment also faced by Star Trek: The Next Generation actor {b}Wil Wheaton{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1972!
Peter, Paul and Mary released their cover of Bob Dylan's {b}"Blowin' in the Wind"{!reset} on this day in 1963. Their version would reach #2 o the Billboard Hot 100.
Help, ~player~! Or rather, {b}Help!,{!reset} the Beatles' second movie, premiered in London on this day in 1965.
On this day in 1991, American heavy metal band Metallica released their single {b}"Enter Sandman."{!reset} It reached #16 on the Billboard Hot 100 and propelled Metallica to worldwide popularity.
