This day in 2005 saw the release of Disney's teen superhero film {b}Sky High,{!reset} also known as My Hero Academi-- hey! Who wrote that?!
Well, this game certainly sank me. But not as hard as the steamboat {b}Brother Jonathan,{!reset} which struck an uncharted rock off the coast of California and sank on this day in 1865.
On this day in 1619, the first Colonial European representative assembly in the Americas, the {b}Virginia General Assembly{!reset}, convened for the first time in Jamestown.
Are you from {b}Baltimore, Maryland{!reset}, ~player~? Yes? No? Either way, bet you didn't know that Baltimore was founded on this day in 1729!
This day in 1932 saw the premiere of Walt Disney's {b}Flowers and Trees,{!reset} the first cartoon short to use Technicolor and the first Academy Award winning cartoon short.
They say that life is a highway, ~player~. Well, the longest national highway in the world, the {b}Trans-Canada Highway{!reset}, was officially opened on this day in 1962!
On this day, but in 1971, during the {b}Apollo 15{!reset} mission, David Scott and James Irwin landed on the Moon with the first Lunar Rover!
On this day, but in 2006, {b}Top of the Pops,{!reset} the world's longest running music show, broadcast its final show on BBC Two. The show had aired for 42 years.
NASA's {b}Mars 2020{!reset} rover mission was launched from Cape Canaveral on this day in 2020. One of the few good things to happen in that year!

English novelist and poet {b}Emily Brontë{!reset} was born on this day in 1818. She is best known for her only novel, Wuthering Heights, which is considered a classic of English literature--but most students just skim my article instead of actually reading it! {smaller}[citation needed]
{b}Henry Ford{!reset}, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, was born on this day in 1863.
Chicago blues singer songwriter and guitarist {b}Buddy Guy{!reset} was born on this day in 1936. He is considered highly influential on numerous later guitarists.
Canadian-American singer-songwriter {b}Paul Anka{!reset} was born on this day in 1941. He is best known for writing "She's a Lady" by Tom Jones and the lyrics for "My Way" by Frank Sinatra.
Hasta la vista, ~player~! Austrian-American actor and bodybuilder {b}Arnold Schwarzenegger{!reset} was born on this day in 1947.
English singer-songwriter {b}Kate Bush{!reset} was born on this day in 1958. Do you like her music, ~player~?
American actress {b}Lisa Kudrow{!reset}, best known for playing Phoebe in the sitcomFriends, was born on this day in 1963. But we are still lacking sources on what they were feeding the Smelly Cat.
Happy {b}International Day of Friendship{!reset}, ~player~! This day is recognized in several countries as a celebration of friendship. We will remain friends after this game is over, right?...
On this day in 1954, {b}a team of Italian climbers{!reset} became the first to reach the summit of {b}K2{!reset}, the world's second-highest mountain.
Well, I certainly erupted back there! But I didn't make nearly as big of one as {b}Mount Fuji{!reset} in Japan, whose oldest recorded eruption took place on this day in 781.

On this day in 177, the U.S. Second Continental Congress commissioned {b}Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette{!reset} of France as a major general in the American Revolution. You may recall Lafayette being a major player in the war as depictd in the Broadway musical Hamilton.
The first U.S. {b}patent{!reset} was issued on this day in 1790, to inventor Samuel Hopkins for a potash process.
On this day in 1874, {b}Dr. Patrick Francis Healy{!reset} became the first African American president of a predominantly white university, Georgetown University.

On this day, but in 1964, the space probe {b}Ranger 7{!reset} sent back the first close-up photographs of the Moon! The images were 1,000 times clearer than anything ever seen from earth-bound telescopes.
On this day in 1971, during the Apollo 15 mission, David Scott and James Irwin became the first astronauts to ride in a {b}Lunar Rover{!reset}! I have always wanted to try one of those...
On this day in 2012, American swimmer {b}Michael Phelps{!reset} broke the record set in 1964 for the most medals won at the Olympics. Do you like to swim, ~player~?
{b}Fred Quimby{!reset}, the American animation producer best known for producing the original Tom and Jerry cartoon series, was born on this day in 1886.
American actor {b}Wesley Snipes{!reset} was born on this day in 1962. What's your favorite film of his, ~player~?

I gotta have that cowbell! American rock band {b}Blue Öyster Cult{!reset} released their single, "(Don't Fear) The Reaper," on this day in 1976. And it has one of the most odd cases of parentheses in any song title on Wikipedia. {smaller}[citation needed]
On this day in 1971, the {b}Concert for Bangladesh{!reset}, a pair of benefit concerts organised by George Harrison and Ravi Shankar, took place at Madison Square Garden in New York City.
British scientist Joseph Priestley discovered {b}oxygen{!reset} gas on this day in 1774, corroborating the discovery of this element by German-Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele.
On this day in 30 BCE, {b}Octavian{!reset}, later known as Augustus Caesar, entered Alexandria, Egypt, bringing it under the control of the Roman Republic.

On this day in 527 CE, {b}Justinian I{!reset} became the sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire. His rule would last until 565, and would bring about a period of prosperity in the empire, including the building of the Hagia Sophia.
This day in 1855 marked the first ascent of {b}Monte Rosa{!reset}, the second highest summit in the Alps! Have you ever gone mountain climbing, ~player~?
Are you from {b}Colorado{!reset}, ~player~? Because on this day in 1876, Colorado was admitted as the 38th U.S. state.
Frank Herbert's novel {b}Dune{!reset} was published for the first time on this day in 1965. And it has struggled to receive a successful film adaptation up to this day...

Do you like 1980s music videos, ~player~? Because on this day in 1981, {b}MTV{!reset} first started broadcasting in the United States! Its first video was "Video Killed the Radio Star" by the Buggles.
Oh say, can you see, ~player~? Today in 1779 was the birthday of {b}Francis Scott Key{!reset}, the lawyer and poet credited for writing "The Star-Spangled Banner."
Happy birthday, {b}Jerry Garcia{!reset}! The lead guitarist and co-lead singer of psychedelic rock band the Grateful Dead was born on this day in 1942.
{b}Boz Burrell{!reset}, the former bassist of King Crimson and founding member of the supergroup Bad Company, was born on this day in 1946.

Do you listen to music while playing this porn game, ~player~? Maybe you should listen to some {b}Coolio{!reset}! The rapper, born on this day in 1963 and best known for his hit song "Gangsta's Paradise," now makes soundtracks for porn, fun fact.
Chubby Checker's hit song {b}"The Twist"{!reset} was released on this day in 1960! Do you know how to dance the Twist, ~player~?
On this day in 1960, {b}Elvis Presley{!reset} was named Public Enemy #1 by the East German newspaper, Young World. Sounds more like a first world problem to me!
On this day in 1492, {b}Christopher Columbus{!reset} set sail from Palos de la Frontera, Spain in search of India. Needless to say, he was unsuccessful.

The first known letter from North America was sent by {b}John Rut{!reset} while at St. John's, Newfoundland, on this day in 1527. Imagine how long that must have taken, to arrive ~player~. Nowadays you can find information on Wikipedia within seconds.
The {b}Firestone Tire and Rubber Company{!reset} was founded on this day in 1900. It still operates, although it is currently owned by the Japanese company Bridgestone.
On this day in the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, Germany, {b}Jesse Owens{!reset} won the 100 metre dash!
{b}Santa Claus Land{!reset} (now known as {b}Holiday World and Splashin' Safari{!reset}), the world's first themed amusement park, opened in the town of Santa Claus, Indiana on this day in 1946.

If you're a fan of basketball, ~player~, this day is important, because the Basketball Association of America and the National Basketball League finalized the merger that would create the {b}National Basketball Association (NBA){!reset} on this day in 1949.
On this day in 1958, the {b}USS Nautilus{!reset}, the world's first nuclear submarine, became the first vessel to complete a submerged transit of the geographical North Pole.

This day in 1900 was the birthday of {b}John T. Scopes{!reset}, the American schoolteacher who stood up for teaching evolutionary theory even when threatened with legal action! He is a hero for those of us who believe in the freedom of education!
{b}Jimmie Nicol{!reset}, the British drummer best known for briefly replacing Ringo Starr of the Beatles in 1964, was born on this day in 1939.

American film director {b}John Landis{!reset}, known for his work on The Blues Brothers, An American Werewolf in London, and the music video for Michael Jackson's "Thriller," was born on this day in 1950!
Happy birthday, {b}James Hetfield{!reset}! YEAH-YEAHHHHH!! The lead singer and rhythm guitarist of Metallica was born on this day in 1963!
On this day in 1963, {b}the Beatles{!reset} made their final appearance at the Cavern Club in Liverpool. They had performed nearly 300 shows at the club since 1961.

On this day in 1987, {b}Def Leppard{!reset} released their album {b i}Hysteria{!reset} after three years of development. It became the band's best-selling album to date, selling over 20 million copies worldwide.

On this day in 1991, an explosion on the Greek cruise ship {b}MTS Oceanos{!reset} ruptured its hull, causing it to sink off the east coast of South Africa. Luckily, all 571 people on board were rescued!
American surveyor {b}James Thompson{!reset} produced the first plat of Chicago on this day in 1830.

This day in 1693 is the date traditionally ascribed to Dom Perignon's invention of {b}champagne{!reset}. It is not clear whether he actually invented champagne; however, he has been credited for developing the techniques used to perfect sparkling wine.
Wow, I sure erupted back there. But not as much as {b}Mount Asama{!reset} in Japan, which erupted in the Tenmei era on this day in 1783 and caused widespread damage.

{b i}The Saturday Evening Post{!reset} was published for the first time on this day in 1823. It was a weekly newspaper until 1963, after which it switched to publishing once every two weeks and then quarterly and ultimately bimonthly.
On this day in 2007, NASA's {b i}Phoenix{!reset} spacecraft was launched for Mars. It would ultimately land on Mars in 2008 and stay operational for 157 sols.
{b}Louis Vuitton{!reset}, the French fashion designer whose brand is mentioned in every hip hop song, {smaller}[citation needed]{!reset} was born on this day in 1821.
Silent film actress {b}Anita Page{!reset} was born on this day in 1910. She acted in 35 films from 1925-1933 and was known as "the girl with the most beautiful face in Hollywood."
{b}Robbin Crosby{!reset}, guitarist for the American metal band Ratt, was born on this day in 1959.
This day was the birthday of former United States President {b}Obama{!reset}! Although our sources are still gathering information on what his last name is...
{b}Cole and Dylan Sprouse{!reset}, the twin actors best known for their roles on The Suite Life of Zack & Cody, were born on this day in 1992. Did you watch that show when you were younger, ~player~?

On this day in 1958, Billboard Magazine introduced its {b i}Hot 100{!reset} chart, which served as a barometer of the movement of potential hits. The first number one song was Ricky Nelson's "Poor Little Fool."
On this day in 1964, {b}the Kinks{!reset} released their single "You Really Got Me." Critics have called this the first punk rock song.

{b}Bertha Benz{!reset}, the wife of automobile innovator Karl Benz, made the first long-distance automobile trip, driving 106 kilometers from Mannheim to Pforzheim, Germany in a Benz Patent-Motorwagen on this day in 1888.
On this day in 2011, NASA launched the {b i}Juno{!reset} probe to Jupiter as part of the New Frontiers program.
Are you a fan of Star Wars, ~player~? Because {b}Sir Alec Guinness{!reset}, the English actor best known for portraying Obi-Wan Kenobi in the original trilogy, was born on this day in 1914.
On this day in 1583, Sir Humphrey Gilbert established the first English colony in North America, at what is now {b}St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador.

On this day in 1620, the {b i}Mayflower{!reset} departed from Southampton, England, carrying would-be settlers, on its first attempt to reach North America! However, it was forced to dock in Dartmouth when its companion ship, the Speedwell, sprung a leak.
The cornerstone for the {b}Statue of Liberty{!reset} was laid on Bedloe's Island (now Liberty Island) in New York Harbor on this day in 1884.
Stop, ~player~! On this day in 1914, the first electric {b}traffic light{!reset} was installed in Cleveland, Ohio, leading to a legacy of infuriating drivers everywhere for decades to come!
On this day in 1926, {b}Harry Houdini{!reset} performed what was seen as his greatest feat, spending 91 minutes underwater in a sealed tank before escaping.

{b i}American Bandstand{!reset}, Dick Clark's show that played the songs and showing popular dances fpr teenagers of the time, debuted on ABC on this day in 1957. Your grandparents probably watched that show, ~player~!
{b}Neil Armstrong{!reset}, the American aviator and astronaut who became the first man to set foot on the Moon, was born on this day in 1930!

Rock and roll, hoochie-coo! {b}Rick Derringer{!reset}, the American musician and producer best known for his solo career and his work with Edgar Winter and "Weird Al" Yankovic, was born on this day in 1947!
I wanna rock! Rock! {b}Eddie "Fingers" Ojeda{!reset}, guitarist for Twisted Sister, was born on this day in 1955.
Foo Fighters and Germs guiarist Georg Albert Ruthenberg, better known by his stage name {b}Pat Smear{!reset}, was born on this day in 1959.
You spin me right round, baby right round, like a record baby right round, round, round... Dead or Alive frontman {b}Pete Burns{!reset} was born on this day in 1959.
You gotta fight! For your right! To party! {b}Adam "MCA" Yauch{!reset}, bassist and MC for the Beastie Boys, was born on this day in 1964!

Do you like the 2002 Scooby-Doo movie, ~player~? What about Guardians of the Galaxy? Or The Suicide Squad? What do those films have in common? Director-writer {b}James Gunn{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1966!

On this day in 1991, British computer programmer {b}Tim Berners-Lee{!reset} first posted files describing his ideas for a system of interlinked, hypertext documents accessible via the Internet, to be called a "World Wide Web. Hmmm... I do not think that ever caught on.
{b}Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor{!reset} first declared the dissolution of the Holy Roman Empire on this day in 1806.
On this day in 1926, {b}Gertrude Ederle{!reset} became the first woman to swim across the English Channel.

In New York City, the Warner Bros.' {b}Vitaphone{!reset} sound system premiered in the movie Don Juan starring John Barrymore on this day in 1926. Vitaphone would remain in use for silent films until 1931.
After releasing their final album, ¡Adios Amigos! the year prior, influential punk band {b}the Ramones{!reset} played their farewell concert at The Palace, Los Angeles, CA on this day in 1996.
On this day in 1996, NASA announced that the {b}ALH 84001{!reset} meteorite, thought to originate from Mars, contains evidence of primitive life-forms.
On this day in 2012, NASA's {b i}Curiosity{b} rover{!reset} landed on the surface of Mars! It it NASA's fourth Mars rover, after Sojourner, Spirit, and Opportunity.

American actress and television producer {b}Lucille Ball{!reset} was born on this day in 1911! Although she is best known for her role as the ditsy titular character in I Love Lucy, did you know that she was the first woman to run a major television studio, and was responsible for airing the original Star Trek series?
American painter, photographer, film director, and Velvet Underground band manager {b}Andy Warhol{!reset} was born on this day in 1928.

Pink Floyd's film version of their album {b i}The Wall{!reset} had its U.S. premiere in New York City on this day in 1982! I feel it would be hypocritical for me to say "we don't need no education," however...
On this day in 1965, {b}the Turtles{!reset} released their cover of Bob Dylan's "It Ain't Me Babe." It became their breakthrough hit and reached #8 on the Billboard Hot 100.
Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan's remake of {b i}Freaky Friday{!reset} was released on this day in 2003. Wouldn't it be strange if you and I were to switch bodies, ~player~?

M. Night Shyamalan's film {b i}The Sixth Sense{!reset} was released on this day in 1999. I would warn you not to read my article on it, as it contains spoilers, but due to pop culture osmosis, you probably already know the film's twist ending.

On this day in 1944, IBM dedicated the first program-controlled calculator, the {b}Automatic Sequence Controlled Calculator{!reset} (best known as the {b}Harvard Mark I{!reset}). Imagine, what once took up an entire building can now fit in your pocket. Isn't it fascinating, ~player~?
On this day in 1959, {b i}Explorer 6{!reset} launched from the Atlantic Missile Range in Cape Canaveral, Florida as part of the Explorer program of satellites.
On this day in 1976, the Mars probe {b i}Viking 2{!reset} entered orbit around Mars! It was the second orbiter-lander in NASA's Viking program.
American puppeteer and costume designer {b}Kermit Love{!reset} was born on this day in 1916. He is best known for his work with the Muppets and is the namesake of Kermit the Frog!
This day in 1958 was the birthday of {b}Bruce Dickinson{!reset}, the longest lasting lead singer of British metal band Iron Maiden! YEAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHH!!!
This day in 1966 was the birthday of {b}Jimmy "Jimbo" Wales{!reset}, the co-founder of Wikipedia! So... do you care to donate in his honor, ~player~?

Did you know that on this day, but in 1679, {b i}Le Griffon{!reset}, a barque built by René-Robert de La Salle, departed on its journey to become the first sailing ship to navigate the upper Great Lakes?
The first {b}Australian rules football{!reset} match was played between Melbourne Grammar and Scotch College on this day in 1858. We have a number of articles about the different types of football!
This day in 1927 saw the opening of the {b}Peace Bridge{!reset}, a 5,800 ft (1.77 km) highway bridge between Fort Erie, Ontario and Buffalo, New York!
On this day in 1985, Takao Doi, Mamoru Mohri and Chiaki Mukai were chosen to become {b}Japan's first astronauts{!reset}!

On this day in 2015, {b i}Fantastic Four{!reset}, stylized on posters as Fant4stic, was released to theaters. It was the third attempted film series with the four--and judging by its reception, it will not be the last!
Fun fact: The {b}first United States census{!reset} was officially completed on this day in 1790! The nation's residential population was enumerated to be 3,929,214.
On this day in 1610, Henry Hudson sailed into what is now known as the {b}Hudson Bay{!reset} in his search for the Northwest Passage.
{b}Tower Subway{!reset}, the world's first underground tube railway, opened in London, England on this day in 1870!
Have you ever seen {b}San Francisco's famous cable car system{!reset}, ~player~? Because the Clay Street Hill Railroad began operating San Francisco's first cable car on this day in 1873.
The {b}positron{!reset}, the antiparticle of the electron, was discovered by Carl D. Anderson on this day in 1932.

Wow, I sure crashed and burned at this game. But not as hard as the British South American Airways Avro Lancastrian airliner Stardust, which {b}crashed into a mountain in Argentina{!reset} on this day in 1947 and whose wreckage would not be found until 1998.
The {b}Helsinki Metro{!reset}, the first rapid transit system of Finland, opened to the public on this day in 1982.
Take a load off, ~player~! Take a load for free! {b}Garth Hudson{!reset}, the Canadian keyboardist and saxophone player for The Band, was born on this day in 1937.

Do you like horror movies, ~player~? Because influential horror director {b}Wes Craven{!reset}, creator of such films as A Nightmare on Elm Street, The Last House on the Left, and Scream, was born on this day in 1939.

If you're playing this game, that probably means that you are a massive nerd. {smaller}[citation needed]{!reset} So you must have some kind of thoughts on the works of film director {b}Kevin Smith{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1970!
Well, we sure misbehaved a bit in this game. Unlike {b}Fats Waller{!reset}, who recorded his classic song "Ain't Misbehavin'" on this day in 1929.
On this day in 1961, {b}the Beatles{!reset} began their engagement as regular headliners at Liverpool's {b}Cavern Club{!reset}. They performed about 300 shows over the next two years.
The oft-parodied album cover photograph of the Beatles' {b i}Abbey Road{!reset} was taken by photographer Iain Macmillan at a zebra crossing in London on this day in 1969.

Did you know that actress {b}Esther Williams{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1921, started as an Olympic-level swimmer but went into acting after the 1940 Olympics were cancelled due to World War II?
{b}Uraniborg{!reset}, Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe's observatory on the island of Hven, had its cornerstone laid on this day in 1576.
On this day in 1876, Thomas Edison received a patent for his {b}mimeograph{!reset}, an early low-cost duplicating machine that worked by forcing ink through a stencil onto paper.
This day was an important day for aviation in 1908, as this was the day when {b}Wilbur Wright{!reset} made his first public flight at a racecourse at Le Mans, France!

The airship {b}LZ 127 {b i}Graf Zeppelin{!reset} began its famous round-the-world flight on this day in 1929. The entire trip took took 21 days, 5 hours, and 31 minutes--the fastest circumnavigation of the globe at the time!
Rap group N.W.A released their debut studio album {b i}Straight Outta Compton{!reset} on this day in 1988. The album received gangsta rap's first platinum certification in July of the following year!

This game really made some of us collapse under the stress. But not as hard as the {b}Warsaw Radio Mast{!reset}, once the tallest humanmade structure ever standing, which collapsed on this day in 1991.

Did you know that submarines were being used as far back as the Civil War? Built in Mobile, Alabama in 1863, the {b i}H. L. Hunley{!reset} was the first combat submarine to sink a warship, and was raised to the surface after 136 years on the ocean floor on this day in 2000.

{b}The first night baseball game in the history of Chicago's Wrigley Field{!reset} took place on this day in 1988. The decision to hold games at night was a source of controversy at the time, due to the possibility of light and noise pollution.
The {b}29th modern summer Olympic Games{!reset} began in Beijing, China on this day in 2008.
{b}Anton Fig{!reset}, the South African-American drummer best known for his work in Paul Shaffer's band, was born on this day in 1952.
U2's guitarist, David Howell Evans, better known as {b}The Edge{!reset}, was born on this day in 1961. For other uses, please see The Edge (disambiguation).
On this day in 1983, {b}Metallica{!reset} released their debut single "Whiplash," from their first album Kill 'Em All.

Today is {b}International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples{!reset}, ~player~! It is observed to raise awareness and protect the rights of the world's indigenous population, as well as to recognize the contributions that indigenous people make to improve world issues such as environmental protection.

The Nez Perce and the United States Army took part in the {b}Battle of the Big Hole{!reset} on this day in 1877... heh... given what we are doing right now, anything with the word "big hole" in its name sounds a lot dirtier than intended.

On this day in 378 CE, a large Roman army led by Emperor Valens was defeated by the Visigoths in the {b}Gothic War{!reset}. And no, despite what vandals may have told you, they were not fighting over big tiddy goth GFs.
On this day in 1173, construction began on the campanile of the Cathedral of Pisa, now known as the {b}Leaning Tower of Pisa{!reset}. It took two centuries to complete!
The {b}Webster–Ashburton Treaty{!reset} was signed on this day in 1842. This established the United States–Canada border east of the Rocky Mountains.
On this day in 1892, Thomas Edison received a patent for a {b}two-way telegraph{!reset}.
{b}Jesse Owens{!reset} won his fourth gold medal during the Summer Olympic Games on this day in 1936!
The United States Forest Service and the Wartime Advertising Council release posters featuring the mascot {b}Smokey Bear{!reset} for the first time on this day in 1944.

On this day in 1973, the USSR launched the {b i}Mars 7{!reset} probe, the final mission in their Mars program; however, due to a malfunction, the lander missed the surface of Mars and instead remained in heliocentric orbit, in one of spaceflight's biggest oopsies!
Did you know that Singapore is the only country to date to ever gain its independence unwillingly? It was {b}expelled{!reset} from Malaysia on this day in 1965.

This day in 1939 was the birthday of {b}The Mighty Hannibal{!reset}! ...No, not that Hannibal. I mean James Timothy Shaw, the funk singer-songwriter and producer known for his 1966 R&B hit "Hymn No. 5."
Happy birthday, {b}Sam Elliott{!reset}! The low-voiced actor known for his roles in Tombstone and The Big Lebowski was born on this day in 1944.
Are you a connoisseur of art, ~player~? Because the {b}Louvre{!reset} in Paris, the world's most visited museum, officially opened on this day in 1793.

Happy birthday, {b}Antonio Banderas{!reset}! The Spanish actor known initially for his Spanish language films, and later known for films such as The Mask of Zorro, Evita, and Shrek 2, was born on this day in 1960.

Well, I sure sunk quickly when playing this game... But not as quickly as the Swedish warship {b i}Vasa{!reset}, which sank in the Stockholm harbour after only about 20 minutes of her maiden voyage on this day in 1628.
The {b}Royal Greenwich Observatory{!reset} in London, England had its foundation stone laid on this day in 1675.
On this day in 1776, word of the {b}United States Declaration of Independence{!reset} finally reached London. As you can imagine, news traveled much slower back then than it does now.
Are you from {b}Missouri{!reset}, ~player~? Because did you know that it was admitted as the 24th U.S. state on this day in 1821?

On this day in 1846, the {b}Smithsonian Institution{!reset} was chartered by the United States Congress after James Smithson donates $500,000. Another organization dedicated to spreading knowledge. I have a deep respect for them.
German chemist Felix Hoffmann discovered an improved way of synthesizing acetylsalicylic acid, better known as {b}aspirin{!reset}, on this day in 1897.

On this day in 1948, {b i}Candid Camera{!reset} made its television debut after being on radio for a year as Candid Microphone. The comedy show would last unil the 1970s, with numerous revivals in the years since.
On this day in 1990, the {b i}Magellan{!reset} space probe reached Venus. The spacecraft scanned the surface of Venus with synthetic-aperture radar and measured its planetary gravitational field.

On this day in 2001, the Space Shuttle Discovery was launched on STS-105 to deliver the astronauts of {b}Expedition 3{!reset} to the {b}International Space Station{!reset}. This was the third long-duration stay on the station.

Happy birthday, {b}Leo Fender{!reset}! The founder of Fender Musical Instruments Corporation, best known for its many models of electric guitars, bass guitars, and amplifiers, was born on this day in 1909.

Today is the birthday of b}Ronnie Spector{!reset}, the wife of music producer Phil Spector, the lead singer of the Ronettes, and the "Ronnie" mentioned in the chorus of "Take Me Home Tonight" by Eddie Money.

Everyone get ready to stand on one leg, because today is the birthday of {b}Ian Anderson{!reset}, the lead singer, primary songwriter, rhythm guitarist, and flautist of progressive rock band Jethro Tull!
This day, August 11, is Independence Day in {b}Chad{!reset}. When the country finally received its independence from France in 1960, some would call it a "Chad move."
On this day in 1929, {b}Babe Ruth{!reset} became the first baseball player to hit 500 home runs in his career with a home run at League Park in Cleveland, Ohio.

Did you know that actress {b}Hedy Lamarr{!reset} was also a brilliant inventor? On this day in 1942, she, along with composer George Antheil, received a patent for a {b}Frequency-hopping spread spectrum{!reset} communication system that later became the basis for modern technologies in wireless telephones, two-way radio communications, and Wi-Fi.
On this day in 1962, {b}Vostok 3{!reset} launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, and cosmonaut Andrian Nikolayev became the first person to float in microgravity.

Quarantine did not only become a thing during the 2020 pandemic, nor is it only reserved for pandemics. In fact, the {b i}Apollo 11{!reset} astronauts were only just released from a three-week quarantine after returning from the Moon on this day in 1969. Stay safe, ~player~!
American singer-songwriter {b}Eric Carmen{!reset}, famous for his hit song "All by Myself" and not to be confused with South Park character Eric Cartman, was born on this day in 1949.

Scottish actor {b}Ian McDiarmid{!reset}, best known for his role as Emperor Palpatine in the Star Wars movies, was born on this day in 1944. And I am afraid you will find his Wikipedia page quite operational...
If a problem comes along, you must whip it! {b}Bob Mothersbaugh, Jr.{!reset}, the lead guitarist of American new wave band Devo, was born on this day in 1952.
{b}Joe Jackson{!reset}--not Michael Jackson's father, but the singer behind the 1982 hit "Steppin' Out"--was born on this day in 1954.
Are you into professional wrestling, ~player~? Because pro wrestler Terry Eugene Bollea, better known as {b}Hulk Hogan{!reset}, was born on this day in 1953!
If I had a lisp, I would say that I am feeling very Thor after masturbating. You know who else is Thor? Australian actor {b}Chris Hemsworth{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1983!
On this day in 1973, Jamaican musician {b}DJ Cool Herc{!reset} began rapping at a party in New York City, laying the foundation for hip-hop music! Isn't that cool, ~player~?
If you live in Japan, ~player~, then happy {b}Mountain Day{!reset}! This day is to provide "opportunities to get familiar with mountains and appreciate blessings from mountains."
{b i}Help!{!reset} The Beatles' second movie premiered in the United States on this day in 1965.
"Where were you in '62?" That was the question asked by George Lucas's movie {b i}American Graffiti{!reset}, released on this day not in 1962, but in 1973.

Did you know that on this day, but in 1990, American paleontologist Sue Hendrickson found one of the most complete discovered Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons, nicknamed {b}Sue{!reset}, near Faith, South Dakota?

On this day in 1492, {b}Christopher Columbus{!reset} arrived in the Canary Islands on his first voyage to the New World. Of course, he still believed he was in India, in one of history's famous cases of "Boy, were they wrong!"
American inventor {b}Isaac Singer{!reset} was granted a patent for his improved design of the sewing machine on this day in 1855.

I hope I did not explode too much back there... But if I did, then it is still not as big an explosion as that of RDS-6s ({b}Joe 4{!reset}). the first thermonuclear bomb, which was detonated on this day in 1953.

This day in 1977 saw the first free flight of the {b}Space Shuttle Enterprise{!reset}! Named after the vehicle from Star Trek, although the orbiter never actually went to space, it was highly useful in early tests of the spacecraft.

On this day, but in 1981, International Business Machines Corporation released the {b}IBM Personal Computer{!reset}! Its design had an a substantial influence on the PC market, as the majority of modern personal computers are distant descendants of the IBM PC.
I may have striked out in this game, but did you know that on this day in 1994, Major League Baseball players went on strike, forcing the cancellation of the {b}1994 World Series{!reset}?
Happy birthday to {b}Erwin Schrödinger{!reset}! The Austrian physicist and academic was born on this day in 1887. Although... is it both his birthday... and not?

This day in 1930... *snicker* ...was the birthday of Belgian-French mathematician and academic... *giggle* ...{b}Jacques Tits{!reset}...
{small}Keep it together, you're not a child anymore!

Happy birthday to {b}Mark Knopfler{!reset}! The lead singer and lead guitarist of Dire Straits, best known for the songs "Money for Nothing," "Walk of Life," and "Sultans of Swing," was born on this day in 1949.
Do you like big butts, ~player~? Well, so did rapper {b}Sir Mix-a-Lot{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1963!
Happy {b}World Elephant Day{!reset}! This international annual event is dedicated to the preservation and protection of the world's elephants.

On this day in 1991, Metallica released their self-titled album, commonly referred to as {b}The Black Album{!reset}. It would go 16× Platinum in the United States and become one of the best-selling albums worldwide!
On this day in 1918, {b}Opha May Johnson{!reset} became the first woman to enlist in the United States Marine Corps! Isn't that interesting?
Happy birthday, {b}Sir Alfred Hitchcock{!reset}! The highly influential British filmmaker, known as the "{b}Master of Suspense{!reset}," was born on this day in 1899,

The {b}Apollo 11{!reset} astronauts enjoyed a ticker tape parade in New York City on this day in 1969--nearly three weeks after their return from the Moon! They spent the time in between in quarantine and taking a well-deserved rest.
{b}Annie Oakley{!reset}, the American sharpshooter known who starred in Buffalo Bill's Wild West show and who was the basis for the musical Annie Get Your Gun, was born on this day in 1860.
Romanian-American actor {b}Sebastian Stan{!reset}, largely known for his role in the Marvel Cinematic Universe as Bucky Barnes, was born on this day in 1982.
The singer {b}James Morrison{!reset} was born on... no, not Jim Morrison! I mean the English singer of the same name, who was born on this day in 1984. Not the guy from The Doors!
Happy {b}International Lefthanders Day{!reset}, ~player~! There are a number of famous people who are left-handed, including, yes indeed, one of my two co-writers!
On this day in 1965, American rock band {b}Jefferson Airplane{!reset} made their stage debut at the Matrix Club in San Francisco, California.
The Beatles' soundtrack album {b i}Help!{!reset} premiered in the United States on this day in 1965, two days after the American release of the film of the same name.

On this day in 1967, {b}Fleetwood Mac{!reset} made their stage debut in Great Britain at the Windsor Jazz & Blues Festival; however, though they started as a blues band, they would not achieve worldwide success until the addition of Lindsay Buckingham and Stevie Nicks in 1975.
The cult classic comic book movie {b i}Scott Pilgrim vs. the World{!reset} was released on this day in 2010.

~Player~, have you seen the movie {b i}Tropic Thunder{!reset}, which was released on this day in 2008? If not, why don't you take a step back, and... watch it? I have been advised not to finish that quotation, for I am not Quote-tan.
One of the first music recordings ever made, of Arthur Sullivan's "{b}The Lost Chord{!reset}," was played at a press conference introducing Thomas Edison's phonograph in London on this day in 1888.
Did you know that English rock band The Who released {b}Who's Next{!reset}, their most acclaimed album, on this day in 1971? We should listen to it after the game!
Construction of {b}Cologne Cathedral{!reset}, the most famous landmark in Cologne, Germany, was completed on this day in 1880.
Did you know that France was the first country to introduce {b}motor vehicle registration{!reset}? They first did so on this day in 1893.
On this day in 1885, {b}Japan's first patent{!reset} was issued to the inventor of a rust-proof paint.

This day in 1901 is when aviation pioneer Gustave Whitehead claims he made the {b}first powered flight{!reset} in his No. 21! However, this is often disputed, so the Wright brothers are still more commonly known as the first aviators.

On this day in 1967, the {b}Marine Broadcasting Offences Act{!reset} declared participation in offshore pirate radio illegal in the United Kingdom. It seems the suppression of freedom of information even extends to the music we listen to...

This day in 2003 saw the {b}Northeast blackout of 2003{!reset}, a widespread power outage that affected parts of the Northeastern and Midwestern United States. Nobody there could use Wikipedia for days!
American dentist and gunfighter {b}Doc Holliday{!reset}, best known for his role in the infamous Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, was born on this day in 1851.
Happy birthday, {b}Steve Martin{!reset}! The American actor, comedian, musician, producer, and screenwriter--okay, what doesn't he do?--was born on this day in 1945.
British singer and actress {b}Sarah Brightman{!reset}, best known for originating the role of Christine Daaé in The Phantom of the Opera, was born on this day in 1960.
Happy birthday, {b}Magic Johnson{!reset}! The former point guard of the Los Angeles Lakers and philanthropist was born on this day in 1959.

{b}Halle Berry{!reset}, the American actress best known for her role as Storm in the X-Men movies and worst known for her starring role in Catwoman, was born on this day in 1966. At least she took the Razzie with pride!
On this day in 1989, Bon Jovi's album {b}New Jersey{!reset} became the first American album to be officially released in the USSR.

On this day, but in 1977, the Big Ear radio telescope in Ohio, operated as part of the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) project, received a strong, apparently extraterrestrial radio signal, which became known as the "{b}Wow! signal{!reset}."
This day in 1057 saw the demise of {b}Macbeth, King of Scotland{!reset}, which, surprisingly enough, did not occur in the same way as was described in Shakespeare's play.
The foundation stone of {b}Cologne Cathedral{!reset} was laid on this day in 1248, although construction would not be completed until 1880. Wow!
The {b}Panama Canal{!reset} opened to traffic with the transit of the cargo ship SS Ancon on this day in 1914. And unlike the Suez Canal, it was not blocked on its first day!
{b i}The Wizard of Oz{!reset}, starring Judy Garland, premiered at Grauman's Chinese Theater in Los Angeles, California on this day in 1939.
On this day in 1947, {b}India gained independence{!reset} from British rule after near 190 years of British company and crown rule!
My body may have quaked during my climax, but not as much as the {b}1950 Assam–Tibet earthquake{!reset}, the largest earthquake on land measuring Mw 8.6, which took place on this day in 1950.
On this day in 1965, the Beatles played to nearly {b}60,000 fans at Shea Stadium{!reset} in New York City, an event later regarded as the birth of stadium rock!

On this day in 1969, {b}Woodstock Festival{!reset} opened in upstate New York, featuring some of the top rock musicians of the era and famously drawing in over 400,000 people. Who is your favorite artist that played at Woodstock, ~player~?
On this day in 2013, the Smithsonian announced the discovery of the {b}olinguito{!reset}, the first new carnivorous species found in the Americas in 35 years.

Happy birthday to {b}John "Blind Jack" Metcalf{!reset}, born on this day in 1717! Blind from age six, the diver, swimmer, card player, engineer, and fiddler was best known for his development of 180 miles of turnpike road, and became known as one of the fathers of the modern road.
Scottish novelist {b}Walter Scott{!reset}, best known for his historical novel Ivanhoe, was born on this day in 1771.
{b}Ethel Barrymore{!reset}, American actress regarded as "the First Lady of the American Theatre," and a member of the famous Barrymore family, was born on this day in 1879.

Did you know that {b}Jimmy Webb{!reset} has written hundreds of songs, including classic hits like "MacArthur Park" and "Highwayman," and is still active today? The American singer-songwriter was born on this day in 1946--and has an impressive work ethic!
American actor {b}Ben Affleck{!reset} was born on this day in 1972 and is always regarded as the best Batman. {smaller}[citation needed]
This day in 1875 was the birthday of English composer {b}Samuel Coleridge-Taylor{!reset}! Not to be confused with English poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

The cult classic horror musical comedy {b i}The Rocky Horror Picture Show{!reset} was first released on this day in 1975...
~Player~? Do you want me to finish? I can see you shiver with antici...
On this day in 1896, a group including George Carmack and Keish "Skookum" Jim Mason discovered gold near Dawson City, Canada, setting off the {b}Klondike Gold Rush{!reset}.
Wow, masturbating sure made my body quake... But not as much as the {b}1906 Valparaíso earthquake{!reset}, measuring approximately 8.2 Mw, which struck Chile on this day in 1906.
On this day in 1858, the new U.S. {b}transatlantic telegraph cable{!reset} was inaugurated! However, a weak signal forced a shutdown of the service a few weeks later.

This game really knocked me out... But not as hard as {b}Ray Chapman{!reset} of the Cleveland Indians, who was hit on the head by a fastball thrown by Carl Mays of the New York Yankees on this day in 1920, and later succumbed to his injuries.
On this day in 1927, the {b}Dole Air Race{!reset} began from Oakland, California, to Honolulu, Hawaii. It became infamous as six airplanes were lost or damaged beyond repair.

The first color sound cartoon, {b}Fiddlesticks{!reset}, was released by Ub Iwerks on this day in 1930. Imagine, nobody back then knew that cartoons would eventually progress to strip poker games on the internet.
This day in 1944 saw the first flight of a jet with forward-swept wings, the {b}Junkers Ju 287{!reset}.
The first issue of {b}Sports Illustrated{!reset} was published on this day in 1954! Their swimsuit editions became the joy of many teenagers across America.

On this day in 1960, {b}Joseph Kittinger{!reset} parachuted from a balloon over New Mexico at 102,800 feet (31,300 m), setting three records that held until 2012: High-altitude jump, free fall, and highest speed by a human without an aircraft.
On this day in 1989, {b}a solar particle event{!reset} affected computers at the Toronto Stock Exchange, forcing a halt to trading. Imagine if that happened to Wikipedia's mainframe--that would suck!
This day in 1892 was the birthday of {b}Otto Messmer{!reset}, the American cartoonist and animator best known for co-creating Felix the Cat!
A very happy birthday to {b}Barry Hay{!reset}! The lead singer of Dutch rock band Golden Earring was born on this day in 1948,
Happy birthday, {b}Madonna{!reset}! The pop singer and actress known for her provocative persona and shaping the face of early music videos was born on this day in 1958.
NAACP award-winning actress {b}Angela Bassett{!reset} was born on this day in 1958.
Are you a fan of The Office, ~player~? Because {b}Steve Carell{!reset}, who played Michael Scott, was born on this day in 1962!
Happy birthday, {b}Taika Waititi{!reset}! The film director known for his work on Thor: Ragnarok and Jojo Rabbit was born on this day in 1975.
On this day in 1962, {b}Ringo Starr{!reset} was picked to replace Pete Best as the drummer for the Beatles, a decision that upset many of their longtime fans, but proved successful.
Did you know that, released on this day in 1995, the crime drama {b}The Usual Suspects{!reset} took its title from a line from Casablanca?
On this day in 1907, {b}Pike Place Market{!reset}, one of the oldest continuously operated public farmers' markets in the U.S. and a popular tourist attraction, opened in Seattle, Washington.

{b i}Animal Farm{!reset}, George Orwell's satirical allegory of Soviet totalitarianism, was first published on this day in 1945. Did you have to read that for your high school English class, ~player~? Be honest: did you skim the Wikipedia page when you did?

On this day in 1585, the first group of colonists sent by Sir Walter Raleigh under the charge of Ralph Lane landed in the New World to create {b}Roanoke Colony{!reset} on Roanoke Island, off the coast of present-day North Carolina.

On this day in 1597, Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex, and Sir Walter Raleigh set sail on the {b}Islands Voyage{!reset}, an expedition to the Azores, an archipelago composed of nine volcanic islands about 1,400 km west of Lisbon.
On this day in 1807, Robert Fulton's {b i}North River Steamboat{!reset} left New York City for Albany on the Hudson River, inaugurating the first commercial steamboat service in the world!
On this day in 1958, the U.S. made its first attempt at lunar orbit with the failed launch of a probe that would later come to be known as {b i}Pioneer 0{!reset}.
A magnitude 7.5 earthquake struck near Hebgen Lake in Montana on this day in 1959. The earthquake would create {b}Quake Lake{!reset}, which still exists in Montana to this day!
On this day in 1970, {b i}Venera 7{!reset} was launched to Venus. It later became the first spacecraft to successfully transmit data from the surface of another planet!
On this day in 1977, the Soviet icebreaker {b i}Arktika{!reset} became the first surface ship to reach the North Pole. Some people have told me that I am not so good at icebreakers, myself.
On this day in 1978, {b i}Double Eagle II{!reset} became the first balloon to cross the Atlantic Ocean when it landed in Miserey, France, 137 hours after leaving Presque Isle, Maine!

English poet and playwright {b}Ted Hughes{!reset} was born on this day in 1930. Although he was an accomplished writer, perhaps most famous was his children's literary work, The Iron Man, which would later be adapted into a concept album by Pete Townshend and a popular animated film, The Iron Giant.
You talkin' to me, ~player~? American actor {b}Robert De Niro{!reset} was born on this day in 1943!

A lot of musicians were born on this day, including: {b}Sib Hashian{!reset}, the original drummer for Boston, in 1949; American guitarist {b}Eric Johnson{!reset} in 1954; and singer-songwriter {b}Belinda Carlisle{!reset} in 1958!

Happy birthday to {b}Phoebe Bridgers{!reset}, a singer-songwriter beloved by millennials who was born on this day in 1994! ...Oh, and {b}Lil Pump{!reset}, a much less beloved rapper who was born on this day in 2000.
On this day in 1970, keyboardist {b}Christine McVie{!reset} joined Fleetwood Mac as the group's first female member--but certainly not their last.

Released on this day in 1979, {b i}Monty Python's Life of Brian{!reset} drew ire from religious groups at the time who called it blasphemous; despite that, it became the fourth-highest-grossing film in the United Kingdom that year. The Streisand Effect is at work: tell people not to do something, and they will want to do it.

On this day in 1783, an unusually bright fireball meteor procession blazed across the night sky over Great Britain. The {b}1783 Great Meteor{!reset} was the subject of much discussion and many studies.
On this day in 1920, the {b}Nineteenth Amendment{!reset} to the United States Constitution was ratified, granting women the right to vote! Hurrah!
The first grammar of the Spanish language ({b}Gramática de la lengua castellana{!reset}) was presented to Queen Isabella I on this day in 1492.
On this day in 1868, French astronomer Pierre Janssen discovered {b}helium{!reset}. Records are still unavailable on when it was first discovered that helium can do hilarious things to your voice.
On this day in 1923, London held the 1923 {b}WAAA Championships{!reset}, the first British Track and Field championships for women!

On this day in 2005, a {b}massive power blackout{!reset} hit the Indonesian island of Java, affecting almost 100 million people, one of the largest and most widespread power outages in history. Think about that next time you lose electricity!
{b}Meriwether Lewis{!reset}, the famous American explorer of the West, was born on this day in 1774.
Happy birthday, {b}Robert Redford{!reset}! The American actor, director, activist, and co-founder of the Sundance Film Festival was born on this day in 1936.
I've... had the time of my life... Happy birthday to {b}Patrick Swayze{!reset}! The Dirty Dancing actor was born on this day in 1952.

Happy birthday to {b}Andy Samberg{!reset}! The American actor and comedian, born on this day in 1978, is largely known for his songs with The Lonely Island, including "Dick in a Box," "3-Way," "I Just Had Sex," "Jizz in My Pants"... wow, he is almost as lewd as this game!

On this day in 1969, {b}Woodstock Festival{!reset} finally drew to a close with a performance from Jimi Hendrix. It was supposed to end the day before, but it went over schedule and continued until the morning!

On this day in 1986, Bon Jovi released their third album, {b}Slippery When Wet{!reset}! It contained many of the band's biggest hits, including "Livin' on a Prayer," "You Give Love a Bad Name," and "Wanted Dead or Alive."
This day in 2006 saw the release of the Samuel L. Jackson film {b}Snakes on a Plane{!reset}! A film that everyone knows for that one line, and little else.

Here is a fun fact for you history buffs: On this day in 476 CE, Germanic leader {b}Odoacer{!reset} captured Ravenna and deposed Emperor Romulus Augustus, marking the {b}fall of the Western Roman Empire{!reset}.
Wow, I was shaking back there! But not as much as the {b}2010 Canterbury Earthquake{!reset}, which struck New Zealand's South Island on this day in 2010 and caused up to NZ$40 billion in damages.
On this day in 1607, the {b}Flight of the Earls{!reset} took place in Ireland. Note that despite the name, they were not actually flying, they were sailing after a permanent exile from Ulster.
I was burning hot during my climax... but not as much as London during the {b}Great Fire of London{!reset}, which had its most destructive damage take place on this day in 1666.
On this day in 1774, during the second voyage of Captain James Cook, {b}New Caledonia{!reset} was first sighted by Europeans.
Did you know that Los Angeles was founded as {b}El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora La Reina de los Ángeles{!reset} (The Village of Our Lady, the Queen of the Angels) on this day in 1781?
American entrepreneur George Eastman registered the trademark {b i}Kodak{!reset} and receives a patent for his camera that uses roll film on this day in 1888.
On this day in 1950, Darlington Raceway is the site of the inaugural {b}Southern 500{!reset}, the first 500-mile NASCAR race!
The first live transcontinental television broadcast took place in San Francisco, from the {b}Japanese Peace Treaty Conference{!reset}, on this day in 1951.
On this day in 1972, {b i}The Price Is Right{!reset} premiered on CBS. As of 2021, it is the longest running game show on American television!

On this day in 1998, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, two students at Stanford University, founded a little website called {b}Google!{!reset} (exclamation point included). But you know how that story goes.
Happy birthday, {b}Dick York{!reset}! The American radio, stage, film, and television actor best known for his role on the TV series Bewitched was born on this day in 1928.

{b}Blackie Lawless{!reset}, frontman of American heavy metal band W.A.S.P., who were best known for their song "Animal (Fuck Like a Beast)" being included on the PMRC's Filthy Fifteen, was born on this day in 1956.
We may not have a black hole sun, but today is the birthday of {b}Kim Thayil{!reset}, the lead guitarist of Soundgarden, who was born on this day in 1960!
American singer-songwriter {b}Beyoncé{!reset} was born on this day in 1981. I feel compelled to mention this in case the Beyhive ever targets this game.
This day in 2020 saw the release of Disney's live action remake of {b i}Mulan{!reset}! I wonder how Mulan feels about that film...
On this day in 917 CE, {b}Liu Yan{!reset} declared himself emperor, establishing the state of Southern Han at his capital of Panyu in southern China, located at present-day Guangzhou.
This day in 1905 marked the end of the Russo-Japanese War with the signing of the {b}Treaty of Portsmouth{!reset} in New Hampshire!
"I won't be a rock star, I will be a legend," said the great {b}Freddie Mercury{!reset}, the lead singer and pianist of British rock band Queen, who was born on this day in 1946.
I was burning up during my climax... but not as much as London during the {b}Great Fire of London{!reset}, which ended on this day in 1666.

In an effort to Westernize his nobility, Tsar Peter I of Russia imposes a {b}tax on beards{!reset} for all men except the clergy and peasantry on this day in 1698. A beard tax--hard to imagine, isn't it?

On this day in 1774, the {b}First Continental Congress{!reset} assembled in Philadelphia, which would later be considered the Capital of the United States until Philadelphia's takeover during the American Revolution.
On this day in 1977, NASA launched the {b i}Voyager 1{!reset} spacecraft as part of their Voyager program. As of 2021, we are still receiving signals from it!
On this day in 1984, the {b}Space Shuttle {b i}Discovery{!reset} landed after its maiden voyage, STS-41-D.
On this day in 1996, {b}Hurricane Fran{!reset} made landfall near Cape Fear, North Carolina as a Category 3 storm with 115 mph sustained winds. It ultimately caused over $3 billion in damage!

This day in 1735 was the birthday of {b}Johann Christian Bach{!reset}, a German-English viol player and composer and the eighteenth child of Johann Sebastian Bach! Sex in the Bach family must have really been good if they kept coming back for more...

This day in 1847 was the birthday of American outlaw {b}Jesse James{!reset}! Not to be confused with his son, three athletes, two musicians, two politicians, a car manufacturer, an actor, a rapper, and the Pokémon twins of the same name.
This day in 1912 was the birthday of American composer and music theorist {b}John Cage{!reset}. We shall now celebrate this momentous occasion with four minutes and 33 seconds of silence.

On this day, but in 1939, {b}John Stewart{!reset} was born... no, not Jon Stewart! John Stewart, the American songwriter and musician best known for writing "Daydream Believer" by the Monkees and his solo career that included almost four dozen albums and 600 recorded songs. Talk about work ethic!

{b}Buddy Miles{!reset}, the drummer and vocalist best known for his work solo, with Jimi Hendrix, and as the lead singer of the "California Raisins" commercials--yes, really--was born on this day in 1947.

Did you know that when American actor {b}Michael Keaton{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1951, was chosen to play Batman, people were skeptical and petitioned to have him removed from the film due to his past roles in comedies? How little they knew!
Happy birthday, {b}Brad Wilk{!reset}! The rock drummer known for his work in Rage Against the Machine, Audioslave, Black Sabbath, and Prophets of Rage was born on this day in 1968.
Happy birthday, {b}Dweezil Zappa{!reset}! Born on this day in 1969, the son of famous composer and guitarist Frank Zappa would prove to be a guitar virtuoso himself.

On this day in 1993, guitarist {b}Dave Navarro{!reset} joined the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Although releasing the cult classic album One Hot Minute, Navarro's tenure in the band would be brief, and he would soon be replaced by former guitarist John Frusciante.

This day in 1941 saw the release of Orson Welles's {b i}Citizen Kane{!reset}! Poorly received at the time, it has since undergone a reevaluation and is now considered one of the greatest films of all time.

On this day, but in 1620, the {b}Pilgrims{!reset} set sail from Plymouth, England on the {b}Mayflower{!reset} to eventually settle in North America, after a previous failure to depart on August 5 the same year.
On this day in 1628, Puritans settled in {b}Salem{!reset}, which became part of Massachusetts Bay Colony. And as we know, nothing bad ever happened in Salem...

On this day in 1642, England's Parliament {b}banned public stage-plays{!reset}. This ban started just after the First English Civil War and would last until 1660, after the English Restoration brought King Charles II to effective power in England. This is strange to think about, considering England's history with the theatre...
British scientist {b}John Dalton{!reset} first began using symbols to represent the atoms of different elements on this day in 1803.
On this day, but in 1870, {b}Louisa Ann Swain{!reset} of Laramie, Wyoming became the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally after 1807.
The {b}Monterrey Institute of Technology{!reset} was founded in Monterrey, Mexico on this day in 1943. It became one of the largest and most influential private universities in Latin America.

Sorry if my facts are derailing the conversation... But you know what else was derailed? Pennsylvania Railroad's premier train, the Congressional Limited, which {b}crashed at Frankford Junction{!reset} in Philadelphia on this day in 1943.
On this day in 1968, {b}Swaziland{!reset}, officially the {b}Kingdom of Eswatini{!reset}, became independent from the United Kingdom.

On this day in 1991, the Russian parliament approved the name change of Leningrad back to {b}Saint Petersburg{!reset}. The city had not been known as Saint Petersburg since 1914; it was known as Petrograd from 1914-1924 and as Leningrad from 1924-1991.

This day in 1757 was the birthday of {b}Marie-Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette{!reset}, better known as {b}Lafayette{!reset}, the French military officer who fought in the American Revolutionary War, including the Battle of Yorktown--and according to Lin-Manuel Miranda, was a great rapper!

This day in 1879 was the birthday of {b}Max Schreck{!reset}--not the Batman Returns villain of the same name, but the German actor from the silent film era, best known for his role as the vampire Count Orlok in Nosferatu (1922).

This day was the birthday of influential blues musician {b}Jimmy Reed{!reset} in 1925! Reed was an influence on later musicians such as Elvis Presley, Hank Williams Jr., and the Rolling Stones, who recorded his songs.
Happy birthday, {b}David Allan Coe{!reset}! The famed American outlaw country artist was born on this day in 1939.

He once said, "We don't need no education." While I disagree with the statement, I still have to wish the sincerest happy birthday to {b}Roger Waters{!reset}, the bassist, singer, and songwriter of British progressive rock band Pink Floyd, who was born on this day in 1943!

{b}Michael Winslow{!reset}, the American actor, comedian, and beatboxer known as "The Man of 10,000 Sound Effects," who has appeared in films such as Police Academy and Spaceballs, was born on this day in 1958.
Happy birthday, {b}Scott Travis{!reset}! The longest drummer for both Racer X and Judas Priest, who first joined the latter band in 1990 with Painkiller, was born on this day in 1961.
{b}Dolores O'Riordan{!reset}, the Irish singer-songwriter best known as the frontwoman of the Cranberries, was born on this day in 1971.
Happy birthday, {b}Idris Elba{!reset}! Born in 1972, you may be most familiar with the English actor for his roles in Prometheus, Pacific Rim, and the Thor movies.
On this day in 1961, {b}Bob Dylan{!reset} debuted at the Gaslight Cafe in New York City.

On this day in 1968, {b}Eric Clapton{!reset} recorded his famous guitar solo on The Beatles' "While My Guitar Gently Weeps." This song has been a template for many guitarists in the years since then, including Todd Rundgren, Carlos Santana, and Prince.
On this day in 1927, American inventor {b}Philo Farnsworth{!reset} transmitted the first images using his fully-electronic {b}television{!reset} system.

The English pirate {b}Henry Every{!reset} perpetrated one of the most profitable pirate raids in history with the capture of the Grand Mughal ship Ganj-i-Sawai on this day in 1695. Nowadays, pirates mostly just download free movies from the Internet.

According to American colonial reports, Ezra Lee made the world's first {b}submarine{!reset} attack in the Turtle on this day in 1776, attempting to attach a time bomb to the hull of HMS Eagle in New York Harbor. However, no British records of this attack exist, so this is disputed.
This day in 1856 saw the inauguration of the {b}Saimaa Canal{!reset} between Finland and Russia.
On this day in 1901, the Boxer Rebellion in the Qing Dynasty officially ended with the signing of the {b}Boxer Protocol{!reset}.

On this day in 1906, Alberto Santos-Dumont made the first successful flight of his {b i}14-bis{!reset} aircraft at Bagatelle, France. It was the first manned powered flight to be publicly witnessed by a crowd, as well as the first powered flight made anywhere outside of the United States and the first by a non-Wright airplane.
Cunard Line's ocean liner {b}RMS {b i}Lusitania{!reset} sets sail on her maiden voyage from Liverpool, England, to New York City on this day in 1907.
On this day in 1911, French poet {b}Guillaume Apollinaire{!reset} was arrested and put in jail on suspicion of stealing the Mona Lisa from the Louvre. He was released a week later.
In Atlantic City, New Jersey, the first {b}Miss America Pageant{!reset}, a two-day event, was held on this day in 1921.

The {b}International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol){!reset} was formed on this day in 1923. It is not to be confused with the film, the video game, or the band of the same name, nor with the band's studio album or EP of the same name.
This day in 1997 saw the maiden flight of the {b}Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor{!reset}.

American rockabilly singer-songwriter and guitarist {b}Buddy Holly{!reset}, known for his heavy influence on the genre of rock and roll, was born on this day in 1936. Though he was born Charles Hardin Holley, his name was misspelled on his first record contract and he decided to leave it that way.
Happy birthday, {b}Benmont Tench{!reset}! The keyboardist and co-founding member of Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers was born on this day in 1953.

American award-winning songwriter, musician, and record producer {b}Diane Warren{!reset} was born on this day in 1956. You may be familiar with some of her hits: "Rhythm of the Night" by DeBarge, "If I Could Turn Back Time" by Cher, and "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing" by Aerosmith, among others.
{b}LeRoi Moore{!reset}, the founding saxophonist and flautist of the Dave Matthews Band, was born on this day in 1961.
Synth pioneer {b}Gary Numan{!reset} released the album The Pleasure Principle in the United Kingdom on this day in 1979. The album contained his biggest hit song, "Cars."

{b i}A Momentary Lapse of Reason{!reset}, Pink Floyd's first album since the departure of founding member Roger Waters, was released on this day in 1987. Incidentally, it was released on the day after Waters' birthday...
On this day in 1504, Michelangelo's {b i}David{!reset} statue was unveiled in Piazza della Signoria in Florence. Since then, it has become the subject of many a phallic joke...

The {b i}Tonquin{!reset} set sail from New York Harbor on this day in 1810, with 33 employees of John Jacob Astor's newly created Pacific Fur Company on board. After a six-month journey around the tip of South America, the ship finally arrived at the mouth of the Columbia River and Astor's men establish the fur-trading town of Astoria, Oregon.
On this day, but in 1862, the {b}Millennium of Russia{!reset} monument was unveiled in Novgorod.
The {b}United States Pledge of Allegiance{!reset} was first recited on this day in 1892. Although famously, the line "One nation under God" was not added until 1954, as an anti-Soviet measure.

In a bid to prove that women were capable of serving as military dispatch riders, sisters {b}Augusta and Adeline Van Buren{!reset} arrived in Los Angeles on this day in 1916, completing a 60-day, 5,500 mile cross-country trip on motorcycles.

London was hit by a {b}V-2 rocket{!reset} for the first time on this day in 1944. Although developed for World War II, the V-2 would prove useful to the United States in following years, as it became the basis for the rockets that would eventually go to space.

NASA's {b}Marshall Space Flight Center{!reset} in Huntsville, Alabama was officially dedicated on this day in 1960. MSFC's first mission was developing the Saturn launch vehicles for the Apollo program, and was later the lead center for the Space Shuttle main propulsion and external tank and the International Space Station's design and assembly.
The landmark American science fiction television series {b i}Star Trek{!reset} premiered on this day in 1966 with its first-aired episode, "The Man Trap."

On this day in 2004, NASA's unmanned space probe {b i}Genesis{!reset}, sent to collect a sample of solar wind particles and returned them to Earth for analysis, crash-landed when its parachute failed to open.
American singer-songwriter and guitarist {b}Jimmie Rodgers{!reset}, known as the father of country music, was born on this day in 1897.
Good morning, little schoolgirl... {b}Ron "Pigpen" McKernan{!reset}, the original keyboardist, vocalist, and co-founder of psychedelic rock band the Grateful Dead, was born on this day in 1945.
I guess you're just what I needed! Happy birthday to {b}Benjamin Orr{!reset}, the original bassist and co-lead vocalist of new wave band The Cars!
American Civil Rights activist {b}Ruby Bridges{!reset} was born on this day in 1944.
"So, so what?" What is that today is the birthday of American pop rock singer-songwriter {b}Pink{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1979!

Happy {b}World Physical Therapy Day{!reset}, ~player~! This day is observed to generate awareness about the crucial contribution physiotherapists make to society, enabling people to be mobile, well, and independent.

On this day in 1972, Mott the Hoople released their song "{b}All the Young Dudes{!reset}," which would become a staple of the glam rock era. The song was notably written by David Bowie and was originally meant to be on his album, The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars.

On this day in 1965, the television trade publications Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter ran an ad seeking "Folk and rock musicians-singers for acting roles in new TV series." The final four choices became the stars of the television show {b i}The Monkees{!reset}.
This day in 1960 marked the release of Alfred Hitchcock's classic horror film {b i}Psycho{!reset}! Do you enjoy that film, ~player~?

This day in 1984 saw the passing of French automobile engineer and clothing designer {b}Louis Réard{!reset}, who is most famous for introducing the modern two-piece bikini in July 1946! Oh, where would the world of bathing attire be without him?
On this day in 1979, {b}eight people escaped from East Germany to West Germany{!reset} in a home-made hot air balloon. Even in the most dire situations, ingenuity can be useful!
With the Grito de Dolores, Father Miguel Hidalgo began {b}Mexico's fight for independence from Spain{!reset} on this day in 1810.

On this day in 1863, {b}Robert College{!reset} in Istanbul, the first American educational institution outside the United States, was founded by Christopher Robert. Providing education for people around the world is definitely a cause I can get behind!
On this day in 1880, {b i}The Cornell Daily Sun{!reset} printed its first issue in Ithaca, New York. The Sun is the United States' oldest, continuously-independent college daily.
On this day in 1955, a Zulu-class submarine becomes the first to launch a ballistic missile, the Soviet {b}R-11 Zemlya{!reset}.
{b}TCN-9 Sydney{!reset} became the first Australian television station to commence regular broadcasts on this day in 1956.
The first successful photocopier, the {b}Xerox 914{!reset}, was introduced in a demonstration on live television from New York City on this day in 1959.

Are you a fan of opera, ~player~? Because on this day, but in 1966, the {b}Metropolitan Opera House{!reset} opened at Lincoln Center in New York City with the world premiere of Samuel Barber's opera Antony and Cleopatra.

American blues singer-songwriter, guitarist, and producer {b}B.B. King{!reset}, recognized by AllMusic as "the single most important electric guitarist of the last half of the 20th century," was born on this day in 1925. Do you like his music, ~player~?

Spanish singer, songwriter, and music producer {b}Camilo Sesto{!reset}, perhaps best known for his famed Spanish-language adaptation of Andrew Lloyd-Webber's musical Jesus Christ Superstar, was born on this day nin 1946.
Happy birthday, {b}Kenney Jones{!reset}! The British drummer known as a founding member of the Small Faces and the Faces, and for later joining the Who as their drummer, was born on this day in 1948.
Happy birthday, {b}Dave "The Snake" Sabo{!reset}! The co-lead guitarist of American rock band Skid Row, who was also an early member of Bon Jovi, was born on this day in 1964.

In 2000, September 16 was designated as {b}International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer{!reset} by the United Nations, in commemoration of the date, in 1987, on which nations signed the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

On this day in 1963, the Beatles' single "{b}She Loves You{!reset}" was released in the United States and instantly became a sensation, charting at #1 on the Cash Box Hot 100 and the Billboard Hot 100! And for good reason; it is incredibly catchy. She loves you, yeah, yeah, yeah...

On this day in 1978, American psychedelic rock band the Grateful Dead {b}performed at the Pyramids in Egypt{!reset}. Among notable events from these three nights, the final night's performance on September 16 concurred with a total lunar eclipse. Audio and video from the concerts were released three decades later as Rocking the Cradle: Egypt 1978.
On this day in 1979, the Sugarhill Gang released their single "{b}Rapper's Delight{!reset}." It became heavily influential on the rap genre.

Happy birthday, {b}Henry Louis Gates Jr.{!reset}! The American literary critic, professor, historian, and filmmaker largely known as the host of the television series Finding Your Roots on PBS was born on this day in 1950.

Were you around in 2011, when {b}Occupy Wall Street{!reset}, a protest against corporate influence on democracy, took off? Well, Adbusters, a Canadian anti-consumerist publication, organized the initial Occupy protest at Zuccotti Park in New York City on this day in 2011.
On this day in 1382, Louis the Great's daughter, {b}Mary{!reset}, was crowned "king" of Hungary. The idea of Hungary having a female monarch was unpopular at the time.

On this day, but in 1683, Dutch businessman and scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek wrote a letter to the Royal Society describing "animalcules," which would later become known as {b}protozoa{!reset}. He became known as "the Father of Microbiology." Isn't that fascinating, ~player~?
The {b}Presidio of San Francisco{!reset} was founded on the northern tip of the San Francisco Peninsula in New Spain on this day in 1776.
On this day in 1787, after months of drafting and deliberation, the {b}United States Constitution{!reset} was signed in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
On this day, but in 1849, American abolitionist {b}Harriet Tubman{!reset} escaped from slavery.

My luck certainly plummeted and crashed hard when playing today... But not as much as the Wright Flyer flown by Orville Wright, with Lieutenant {b}Thomas Selfridge{!reset} as passenger, which crashed on this day in 1908, killing Selfridge, who became the first airplane fatality.
Are you a fan of football, ~player~? Because on this day in 1920, the {b}National Football League{!reset} was organized as the American Professional Football Association in Canton, Ohio!
On this day in 1961, the world's first retractable roof stadium, the {b}Civic Arena{!reset}, opened in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

On this day, but in 1976, the {b}Space Shuttle {b i}Enterprise{!reset} was unveiled by NASA! Named after the starship from Star Trek, although the orbiter never actually went to space, it was highly useful in early tests of the spacecraft.

Hope I did not erupt too much during my climax... Although it still would have been less than {b}Fourpeaked Mountain{!reset} in Alaska, which erupted on this day in 2006, marking the first eruption for the volcano in at least 10,000 years.

Did you know that on this day, but in 2013, {b i}Grand Theft Auto V{!reset} was released and earned more than half a billion dollars on its first day? This was even despite the game's backlash due to its depictions of violence... or perhaps it was because of said backlash? See also: The Streisand effect!
Famed country musician {b}Hank Williams{!reset}... the original Hank Williams, was born on this day in 1923.

Happy birthday, astronaut {b}Thomas P. Stafford{!reset}! Born on this day in 1930, he is best known for his missions on Gemini 6A in 1965, Apollo 10 in 1969, and the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project in 1975.

American writer {b}Ken Kesey{!reset}, considered a link between the Beat Generation of the 1950s and the hippies of the 1960s, and widely known for his novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, was born on this day in 1935.
American rapper {b}Flo Rida{!reset} was born on this day in 1979. Did you know that despite what some sources may tell you, his first hit single was titled "Low," not "Apple Bottom Jeans"?
On this day in 1931, RCA Victor Records began demonstrations of the {b}LP (long-playing) phonograph record{!reset}, which played at 33⅓ RPM.

On this day in 1967, American psychedelic rock band {b}The Doors{!reset} appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show and performed "Light My Fire" and "People Are Strange." Their appearance was controversial, as it was supposed to be the first of a few performances on the show, but the others were cancelled after Jim Morrison sang the line, "Girl, we couldn't get much higher."

On this day in 1967, {b}The Who{!reset} appeared on The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour and performed "I Can See for Miles" and "My Generation." An incident occurred with pyrotechnics that singed guitarist Pete Townshend's hair and permanently damaged his hearing. Despite this, the performance drew massive attention to The Who in the United States.

On this day in 1991, Guns N' Roses simultaneously released both discs of the double album {b i}Use Your Illusion I{!reset} and {b i}II{!reset}. Although receiving mixed reviewed, both discs went 7× Platinum in the United States and produced several hits, including "You Could Be Mine," "Don't Cry," and "November Rain."

On this day in 1983, American rock band {b}Kiss{!reset} released their album {b i}Lick It Up{!reset}; to promote the album, they appeared on MTV without their trademark makeup for the first time on the same day. Coincidentally, all four members of Kiss previously released solo albums on this same day five years earlier.
On this day in 1793, the first cornerstone of the {b}United States Capitol{!reset} was laid by George Washington.

On this day, but back in 1837, {b}Tiffany & Co.{!reset}, originally named Tiffany & Young, was founded by Charles Lewis Tiffany and Teddy Young in New York City. Although it later specialized in jewelery, the store was first a "stationery and fancy goods emporium."
This day in 1851 saw the first publication of The New-York Daily Times, which later becomes {b i}The New York Times{!reset}.
The cone geyser {b}Old Faithful{!reset} was observed and named by Henry D. Washburn on this day in 1870. It later became a highly popular sight in Yellowstone National Park.
The annual British lights festival known as the {b}Blackpool Illuminations{!reset} were switched on for the first time on this day in 1879.
Did you know that the {b}Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS){!reset} first went on the air as a radio station on this day in 1927?
On this day in 1948, {b}Margaret Chase Smith{!reset} of Maine became the first woman elected to the United States Senate without completing another senator's term!
On this day, but in 1977, {b i}Voyager I{!reset} took the first distant photograph of the Earth and the Moon together, from a distance of 7.25 million miles. Fascinating, isn't it, ~player~?
On this day in 1984, {b}Joe Kittinger{!reset} completed the first solo balloon crossing of the Atlantic.
Carry on, my wayward son... {b}Kerry Livgren{!reset}, the original lead guitarist and primary songwriter for the American progressive rock band Kansas, was born on this day in 1949.

Hey! Ho! Let's go! Happy birthday, {b}Dee Dee Ramone{!reset}! The bassist, co-lead singer, and founding member of legendary punk band the Ramones was born on this day in 1951. He also had a rap career, but... we do not talk about that.

Filmmaker {b}Mark Romanek{!reset}, best known for directing the music videos for songs such as "Hurt" by Johnny Cash, "Closer" and "The Perfect Drug" by Nine Inch Nails, "Can't Stop" by Red Hot Chili Peppers, and "Shake It Off" by Taylor Swift, was born on this day in 1959. Talk about a varied output!

Australian doctor and medical educator {b}Helen Mayo{!reset}, {small}OBE{!reset}, best known for her work in the creation of several hospitals and care facilities for infants, was born on this day in 1878.
{b}St Pancras railway station{!reset} in London, now the terminus of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link, opened to the public on this day in 1868.

On this day in 959 CE, {b}Edgar the Peaceful{!reset} beame king of all England. While Edgar was not known for being a peaceable man, his name came from the fact that his reign in England was peaceful.
This day in 1791 saw the first session of the {b}French Legislative Assembly{!reset}, which formed--and subsequently disbanded--during the French Revolution.
Via the {b}Third Treaty of San Ildefonso{!reset}, Spain ceded Louisiana to France on this day in 1800. France would sell the land to the United States 30 months later.
{b}Yosemite National Park{!reset} was established by the U.S. Congress on this day in 1890. Have you ever gone there, ~player~? I have heard it is beautiful.
This day in 1903 saw the Boston Americans play the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first game of the modern {b}World Series{!reset}!

On this day in 1908, {b}Ford Model T{!reset} automobiles were offered for sale at a price of $825 in U.S. dollars. The Model T was known as the first affordable automobile, signifying innovation for the rising middle class and becoming a powerful symbol of the United States' age of modernization.
The {b}George Washington Bridge{!reset} in the United States, linking New Jersey and New York, was opened on this day in 1931.
On this day in 1964, Japanese {b i}Shinkansen{!reset} ("bullet trains") began high-speed rail service from Tokyo to Osaka.
The {b}CTV Television Network{!reset}, Canada's first private television network, was launched on this day in 1961.
