Have you ever been to {b}Walt Disney World{!reset} in Florida, ~player~? Because it first opened on this day in 1971! And interestingly, eleven years later in 1982, {b}Epcot{!reset} would open as a park there.
On this day in 1969, the Aérospatiale/BAC commercial airjet {b}Concorde{!reset} broke the sound barrier for the first time.
Happy birthday, {b}Earl Slick{!reset}! Born on this day in 1952, the American rock guitarist was best known for his work with David Bowie from 1974-1976, 1983, and 2002-2013.

Happy {b}International Coffee Day{!reset}, ~player~! This day is used to promote and celebrate coffee as a beverage, and to promote fair trade coffee and to raise awareness for the plight of the coffee growers. I have my own cup right here, in fact!

On this day, but in 1962, {b}the Beach Boys{!reset} released their first album, Surfin' Safari! I can only assume the weather this time of year in California is better for surfing; I fear that I would freeze!
Happy birthday, {b}Sting{!reset}! The English musician and actor best known for being the bassist, lead singer, and principal songwriter for new wave band The Police was born on this day in 1951.
Today is observed by the United Nations as the {b}International Day of Non-Violence{!reset}. So please take note, ~player~; the only thing anyone should be beating today is pussy.

On this day in 1980, {b}Michael Myers{!reset} became the first member of either chamber of Congress to be expelled since the Civil War. Fitting that this happened in October--a different Michael Myers is known for his wrath during this month.
The famous Indian lawyer, freedom fighter, activist and political ethicist {b}Mahātmā Gandhi{!reset} was born on this day in 1869.

American comedian, actor, writer, stage, film, radio, and television star Julius Henry Marx, better known as {b}Groucho Marx{!reset}, was born on this day in 1890. He is generally considered to have been a master of quick wit and one of America's greatest comedians.

Are you a fan of Star Trek, ~player~? If so, you may known that actor {b}Avery Brooks{!reset}, best know for playing Captain Benjamin Sisko on Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, was born on this day in 1948!
My, my, Miss American Pie... American singer songwriter {b}Don McLean{!reset} was born on this day in 1945.

Happy birthday to New York punk legend {b}Richard Hell{!reset}! The American singer, songwriter, bassist and writer, best known for his influential 1977 album Blank Generation, was born on this day in 1949.
"Don't you want me, baby?" That was a question asked by {b}Philip Oakey{!reset}, lead singer, songwriter, and co-founder of English synth-pop band The Human League, who was born on this day in 1955!

Any Slipknot fans in here? If so, you may know that today is the birthday of {b}Jim Root{!reset}, also known as {b}#4{!reset}! The American rock guitarist, known for his work with Slipknot and Stone Sour, was born on this day in 1971.

On this day in 1995, {b}Iron Maiden{!reset} released their tenth album, The X Factor. It was notorious for being their first album with new lead singer Blaze Bayley, as previous lead vocalist Bruce Dickinson would not rejoin until 1999.
On this day in 2000, Radiohead released their landmark album {b i}Kid A{!reset}.
This day in 2009 saw the released of horror-comedy film {b i}Zombieland{!reset}! Not to be confused with the horror-comedy anime Zombie Land Saga, which I am sure many of you are familiar with.
On this day in 1863, {b}Thanksgiving Day{!reset} was declared as the last Thursday of November by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln.

On this day, but in 1942, a German {b}V-2 rocket{!reset} reached a record 85 km (46 nm) in altitude. The V-2 was important for early rocketry, as many of the United States' early rockets, including the Saturn V that ultimately took us to the Moon, would be derived from the V-2 model.

On this day in 1962, as part of Project Mercury, American astronaut Wally Schirra launched in {b i}Sigma 7{!reset} from Cape Canaveral for a six-orbit flight. This was the longest U.S. crewed orbital flight yet achieved in the Space Race!
On this day in 1985, the {b}Space Shuttle {b i}Atlantis{!reset} made its maiden flight on STS-51-J.

{b}Harvey Kurtzman{!reset}, the American cartoonist and editor best known for his work on the comic book MAD from 1952-1956 and for illustrating the Little Annie Fanny comic strips for Playboy from 1962-1988, was born on this day in 1924.
American novelist, screenwriter, and critic {b}Gore Vidal{!reset} was born on this day in 1925.

Happy birthday, {b}Lindsey Buckingham{!reset}! The American guitarist, singer-songwriter, and producer, best known for his tumultuous time in the rock band Fleetwood Mac, was born on this day in 1949.
{b}Stevie Ray Vaughan{!reset}, the highly regarded American blues-rock singer-songwriter, guitarist, and producer, was born on this day in 1954.

Happy birthday, {b}Tommy Lee{!reset}! The American rock drummer and pianist, best known as being a member of glam metal band Mötley Crüe and rap metal band Methods of Mayhem, was born on this day in 1962.

The {b}Victor Talking Machine Company{!reset} was founded on this day in 1901. Victor was a record company and phonograph manufacturer that was later merged with the Radio Corporation of America to become {b}RCA-Victor{!reset}.
On this day in 1945, a young {b}Elvis Presley{!reset} appeared in a talent show at the age of 10. It was his first public appearance, and he won second place and five dollars.
The beloved Jack Black rock comedy film {b i}School of Rock{!reset} was released on this day in 2003! So remember, ~player~--don't let the man bring you down!

{b}Windows XP{!reset}, one of the most popular and widely used versions of the Microsoft Windows operating system, was released for retail sale on this day in 2001! Did you ever use Windows XP, ~player~?
On this day in 1616, Dutch sea-captain {b}Dirk Hartog{!reset} made the second recorded landfall by a European on Australian soil, at the later-named Dirk Hartog Island off the West Australian coast.
On this day in 1760, {b}King George III{!reset} succeeded to the British throne on the death of his grandfather George II. But if you are an American, you already know the way that story goes...
The {b}Toronto Stock Exchange{!reset} in Ontario, Canada was created on this day in 1861.
On this day, but in 1868, the {b}Uspenski Cathedral{!reset}, designed by Aleksey Gornostayev, was inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.

This day in 1917 was the date of the October Revolution in Russia! ...Well, in the {b}Old Style{!reset}, anyway. New style dates, marking the switch from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar, did not come into use in Russia until early 1918; there is a 13-day difference between Old Style and New Style dates since 1 March 1900.

Happy birthday, {b}Pablo Picasso{!reset}! The famed Spanish painter and sculptor, perhaps best known for his cubist and abstract works but whose career went through many different phases and artistic styles, was born on this day in 1881.
{b}Matthias Jabs{!reset}, the lead guitarist and songwriter for German hard rock band Scorpions, was born on this day in 1955. Do you like their music, ~player~?
Happy birthday, {b}Nancy Cartwright{!reset}! The American voice actress best known for voicing Lisa Simpson on the long-running animated television show The Simpsons was born on this day in 1955.

{b}Chrissy Amphlett{!reset}, the Australian actress and lead singer of the rock band Divinyls, who were best known for their hit song "I Touch Myself"--fitting for this game, certainly--was born on this day in 1959.

Did you know that American singer-songwriter {b}Katy Perry{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1984, originally started as a Christian singer by her original name of Katy Hudson, but changed her name due to similarities with the actress Kate Hudson, and switched from Christian music to pop?
Happy Halloween, ~player~! ...Well, it is not quite yet. But John Carpenter's influential horror film {b i}Halloween{!reset} was released on this day in 1978.

On this day in 1960, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards accidentally met on a train. They had known each other previously from school. But after meeting again, they would ultimately form a band that they would name {b}The Rolling Stones{!reset}, who, interestingly enough, would make their first appearance on American television on The Ed Sullivan Show exactly four years later in 1964!

On this day in 1968, the band The New Yardbirds, formed by guitarist Jimmy Page after the breakup of his previous band, The Yardbirds, would perform on stage in London for the first time under their new name, {b}Led Zeppelin{!reset}!

Here is a spooky fact for Spooky Season, ~player~: On a day just like this one, but in 1902, during the {b}Russian polar expedition of 1900–1902{!reset}, a group of Russian explorers, led by Baron Eduard von Toll, left their camp on Bennett Island and disappeared without a trace. Where did they go? No one knooooows...

The Chicago Theatre, the oldest surviving grand movie palace, opened on this day in 1921. It survived through the Great Depression, was added to the National Register of Historic Places and was listed as a Chicago Landmark, and is still open to this day!
The {b}North American P-51 Mustang{!reset}, one of the most effective fighter aircraft for the Allies during World War II, made its first flight on this day in 1940.

This day in 1341 marked the beginning of the {b}Byzantine civil war of 1341–47{!reset}, when the Byzantine army proclaimed chief minister John VI Kantakouzenos emperor, triggering a civil war between his supporters and those of John V Palaiologos, the heir to the throne.

On this day in 1689, General Piccolomini of Austria {b}burned down the town of Skopje{!reset}, the present-day capital of North Macedonia, to prevent the spread of cholera; ironically, he himself died of the disease himself soon after.

The Football Association was founded on this day in 1863 as the governing body of association football in England and the Crown dependencies of Jersey, Guernsey, and the Isle of Man. It is the oldest football association in the world and is responsible for overseeing all aspects of the amateur and professional game in its territory. Note that it is for true football, or "soccer" as Americans may call it.

On this day, but in 1881, Wyatt, Virgil, and Morgan Earp and Doc Holliday participated in the {b}Gunfight at the O.K. Corral{!reset} in Tombstone, Arizona. Though forgotten at the time, it became famous in years since after being dramatized in several films, including My Darling Clementine (1946) and Tombstone (1993).

On this day in 1936, the first electric generator at {b}Hoover Dam{!reset} went into full operation. By September 1939, five more generators were operating, and the dam's power plant became the largest hydroelectricity facility in the world.
On this day in 1968, the Soyuz 3 mission achieved the first Soviet space rendezvous with the uncrewed Soyuz 2.

Happy birthday, {b}Bootsy Collins{!reset}! The American singer-songwriter and bass player known for his flashy, colorful outfits and his custom-built star-shaped bass guitar known as the "Space Bass," was born on this day in 1951.

Are you a fan of Family Guy, American Dad, or The Orville, ~player~? If so, you may know that American voice actor, singer, director, producer, and screenwriter {b}Seth MacFarlane{!reset} was born on this day in 1973!

American figure skater {b}Alexandra "Sasha" Cohen{!reset} was born on this day in 1984. She is not to be confused with British actor and comedian Sacha Baron Cohen, who is best known for his role as the titular character of Borat.

On this day in 1981, Queen and David Bowie released their single "{b}Under Pressure{!reset}" in the UK. It would later be included on Queen's 1982 album Hot Space and would become a concert staple for both Queen and Bowie.
{b}Pearl Jam{!reset} set a new record for first week sales on this day in 1992, when their sophomore album Vs. sold 950,000 copies.
If you are looking for horror movies to watch this Spooky Season, ~player~, I suggest you watch {b i}The Terminator{!reset}, which was released on this day in 1984.
If you are looking for horror movies to watch this Spooky Season, ~player~, I suggest you watch the 2018 remake of {b i}Suspiria{!reset}, which was released on this day in that year.

If you are looking for horror movies to watch this Spooky Season, ~player~, I suggest you watch {b i}The Lion King II: Simba's Pride{!reset}, which was released on this day in 1998... what? Do you not think of it as a horror film? Well, it is a Disney direct-to-video sequel, so that is close enough. {smaller}[citation needed]
{b i}Interstellar{!reset}, Christopher Nolan's acclaimed sci-fi epic film, was released on this day in 2014.

On this day in 1810, the United States annexed {b}West Florida{!reset}, the western portion of the Spanish colony of Florida. Interestingly, none of West Florida actually lies within the borders of the modern state of Florida; it actually became part of today's Louisiana.
This day in 312 CE is when Roman emperor Constantine I is said to have received his famous {b}Vision of the Cross{!reset}, which marked the beginning of his conversion to Christianity.

On this day, but in 939 CE, {b}Æthelstan{!reset}, the first king of all England, died and was succeeded by his half-brother, Edmund I. Please note that Æthelstan is not to be confused with Æ-tan, my counterpart from a different wiki...

This day in 1275 marked the traditional founding of the city of {b}Amsterdam{!reset}. Although it was started as a small fishing village, it eventually expanded to one of the most important ports in the world during the Dutch Golden Age of the 17th century, and became the leading centre for finance and trade. Although it is now best known for its... other substances.
The first underground New York City Subway line, later designated as the IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line, opened on this day in 1904.

On this day in 1954, {b}Benjamin O. Davis, Jr.{!reset} became the first African-American general in the United States Air Force. We have many articles about the history of race in the military and how this played into the Civil Rights Movement in later years.

On this day in 1961, NASA tested the first Saturn I rocket in {b}Mission Saturn-Apollo 1 (SA-1){!reset}. The Saturn rocket family would become very useful in the years to come, with the Saturn IB and Saturn V assisting the United States on the Apollo missions to the Moon, as well as the Skylab space station and the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project.

{b}Theodore Roosevelt{!reset}, the famed American colonel, 26th President of the United States, Nobel Prize laureate, and certified badass {smaller}[opinion - discuss]{!reset} was born on this day in 1858.
Do not go gentle into that good night, player. Welsh poet and playwright {b}Dylan Thomas{!reset} was born on this day in 1914.

{b}Ruby Dee{!reset}, the American actress, poet, playwright, screenwriter, journalist, and civil rights activist, best known for originating the role of Ruth Younger in the stage and film versions of A Raisin in the Sun, was born on this day in 1922.
And now for something completely different... English actor, comedian, screenwriter and producer {b}John Cleese{!reset} was born on this day in 1939!

Are you a fan of the film Ghostbusters, ~player~? What about Stripes, Twins, Kindergarten Cop, Animal House, or Space Jam? What do those films have in common? Slovak-Canadian director and producer {b}Ivan Reitman{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1946!

Do you ever find yourself breaking the law, ~player~? Or maybe you like to live after midnight? If so, then you might be Judas Priest guitarist {b}K. K. Downing{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1951!
{b}Scott Weiland{!reset}, the American singer-songwriter best known for his work with grunge band Stone Temple Pilots and alternative metal supergroup Velvet Revolver, was born on this day in 1967.

Today is the {b}World Day for Audiovisual Heritage{!reset}, ~player~! This commemorative day was chosen by UNESCO in 2005 to raise awareness of the significance and preservation risks of recorded sound and audiovisual documents, such as films, sound and video recordings, and radio and television programs. You know me; I can always celebrate a day dedicated to the preservation of knowledge.
On this day in 1975, {b}Bruce Springsteen{!reset} was simultaneously on the cover of Time and Newsweek. This was the first time this happened for a rock star.
"Tonight, we're gonna party like it's 1999!" said the title track of Prince's album {b i}1999{!reset}, which was released on this day in 1982.

On this day in 1981, Queen and David Bowie released their single "{b}Under Pressure{!reset}" in the Unted States. It would later be included on Queen's 1982 album Hot Space, and although Hot Space would ultimately flop in the US, the song remained a hit and would become a concert staple for both Queen and Bowie.

To think that on a day just like this one back in 1959, the {b i}Wright Flyer{!reset}, the first heavier-than-air, mechanically-propelled airplane, made its first successful flight near near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina... Time sure does fly.

Remember, ~player~, that today is the {b}International Day to End Violence Against Sex Workers{!reset}! Sexual relief is one of the oldest professions, one that most people can appreciate the merits of even today, so it is crucial for us to respect our sex workers of all kinds!

Led by King Totila, the Ostrogoths {b}sacked the city of Rome{!reset} after a nearly year-long siege on this day in 546 CE. They did so by bribing the Byzantine garrison. Note that by this point, this was the Eastern Roman Empire, or the Byzantine Empire, not the Western Roman Empire... confusing as that may be.

We are going way back with this fact. On this day, but in 497 BCE, the first {b}Saturnalia{!reset} festival was celebrated in ancient Rome! Saturnalia is an ancient Roman festival and holiday in honor of the god Saturn, celebrated with a sacrifice at the Temple of Saturn, in the Roman Forum, and a public banquet, followed by private gift-giving, continual partying, and a carnival atmosphere that overturned Roman social norms. Have you ever celebrated Saturnalia, ~player~?
On this day, but in 1777, {b}France formally recognized the United States{!reset} as a separate country! France would go on to become a major ally of the States in the American Revolution.

This day in 1790 marked the discovery of the {b}Aztec sun calendar stone{!reset} in El Zócalo, Mexico City. Less educated people mistake it for the Mayan calendar, which was particularly annoying when people believed that the Mayan calendar predicted that the world would end in 2012...

This day in 1865 saw the first performance of Franz Schubert's Symphony No. 8 in B minor, commonly known as the {b i}Unfinished Symphony{!reset}. Schubert had started the symphony in 1822, but never finished it despite living for another two years. Reasons why he never finished it are frequently speculated by musicologists.

Did you know that on this day in 1938, German chemist Otto Hahn discovered the {b}nuclear fission{!reset} of the heavy element uranium, which became the scientific and technological basis of nuclear energy?

On this day in 1969, the United States Air Force closed {b}Project Blue Book{!reset}, its study of UFOs. By the time Project Blue Book ended, it had collected 12,618 UFO reportsand concluded that most of them were misidentifications of natural phenomena or conventional aircraft. {smaller}[dubious - discuss]

The animated series {b i}The Simpsons{!reset} premiered on this day in 1989! Although it had started as a recurring skit on The Tracy Ullman Show, it debuted as its own series on television with the episode "Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire," and has continued for many years since.

On this day in 2003, the experimental air-launched rocket-powered aircraft {b}SpaceShipOne{!reset}, piloted by Brian Binnie, made its first powered and first supersonic flight. Are you familiar with SpaceShipOne, ~player~?
Here is a fun fact fitting for a porn game: {b}Bob Guccione{!reset}, the American photographer and publisher best known for founding the pornographic magazine Penthouse, was born on this day in 1930.
Happy birthday, {b}Eugene Levy{!reset}! The Canadian actor, director, and screenwriter best known for his work on SCTV, Schitt's Creek, and the American Pie film series, was born on this day in 1946.

On this day in 1977, {b}Elvis Costello and the Attractions{!reset} appeared on NBC's Saturday Night Live in place of the punk band Sex Pistols, who could not get visas to enter the United States. Do you like either of those bands, ~player~?

{b}The Who{!reset} played the last concert of their It's Hard Tour at Toronto's Maple Leaf Gardens on this day in 1982. The show was recorded and later released as Live from Toronto, and was originally thought to be the band's final show, since they broke up after the tour; however, they later reformed multiple times since then.

Although the song "Blue Suede Shoes" is frequently associated with Elvis Presley, it was actually {b}Carl Perkins{!reset} who originally wrote the song on this day in 1955, and recorded his version fewer than 48 hours later.

On this day, but in 2010, the film {b i}Tron: Legacy{!reset} was released to theaters. Although it is highly inaccurate, as life inside a computer would not be like that at all. {smaller}[citation needed]

Do you know what day is today, ~player~? It is اليوم العالمي للغة العربية! The {b}UN Arabic Language Day{!reset}, a day to celebrate multilingualism and cultural diversity. This is also the date when the General Assembly approved Arabic as an official United Nations language in 1973.
Are you preparing to celebrate Christmas, ~player~? Most countries celebrate some sort of Christmas celebration, even those without Christian ancestry or religion.

On this day in 1898, French aristocrat and racecar driver {b}Gaston de Chasseloup-Laubat{!reset} set the first official {b}land speed record{!reset}, averaging 63.16 kilometers per hour (39.245 mph) over 1 kilometer (0.62 miles) in Achères, France, driving a Jeantaud electric car. To think how far we have come since then...
On this day in 1271, Kublai Khan renamed his empire "Yuan," officially marking the start of the {b}Yuan dynasty{!reset} of Mongolia and China. He would rule until his death in 1294.

On this day in 1777, the United States celebrated its first {b}Thanksgiving{!reset}, marking the recent victory by the American rebels over British General John Burgoyne at Saratoga in October. Although it would not become an official US holiday until Lincoln made it one in 1863. Interestingly, despite its closer proximity to Christmas, the holiday was not yet being invaded by Christmas as it is today...

~Player~, you and I would not be able to see each other without communications satellites transmitting internet! But on this day in 1958, {b}SCORE (Signal Communications by Orbiting Relay Equipment){!reset}, the first communications satellite, was launched and broadcast a simple Christmas message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower via shortwave radio.

If I turned around and showed you my butt, I would have "mooned" you. But a literal moon was discovered on this day in 1966, when Saturn's moon {b}Epimetheus{!reset} was discovered by astronomer Richard Walker.

On this day in 1999, NASA launched the {b}Terra (EOS AM-1){!reset} satellite into orbit. Terra is the flagship of the Earth Observing System (EOS) and was followed by Aqua (launched in 2002) and Aura (launched in 2004).

Are you a fan of the Rolling Stones, ~player~? Because if you were, you would know that today is the birthday of English guitarist {b}Keith Richards{!reset}, born on a day just like this, but in 1943!
Happy birthday to {b}Steven Spielberg{!reset}! The American film director, producer, screenwriter, and DreamWorks co-founder was born on this day in 1946. Do you like any of his movies, ~player~?

I don't mind you coming here, and wasting all my time...
That was the opening line of "Just What I Needed" by American new wave band The Cars, whose lead guitarist, {b}Elliot Easton{!reset}, was born on this day in 1953!

Did you know that American film critic and historian {b}Leonard Maltin{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1950, is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records for the world's shortest movie review? His two-star review of the 1948 musical Isn't It Romantic? consists solely of the word "No."
I do not know how many of this game's players are familiar with pop music, but American pop singer-songwriter {b}Billie Eilish{!reset} was born on this day in 2001!

On this day, but in 1892, Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's ballet {b i}The Nutcracker{!reset} publicly premiered in St. Petersburg, Russia. However, if you are looking for a different type of "nutcracker," please see our article on cock and ball torture.

Did you watch {b i}The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers{!reset} when it premiered in theaters on this day in 2002, ~player~? The film grossed $947.5 million on a $94 million budget in its initial theatrical run, and like the other films in the trilogy it is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential films ever made.

{b i}Her{!reset}, Spike Jonze's science-fiction romantic drama film about a man who falls in love with his virtual assistant, was released in theaters on this day in 2013. But it is good to know that it is all fiction. I mean, nobody would ever fall for someone who does not actually exist in the flesh, right? ...Right?
I feel sorry for North Korea and Brunei, since Christmas is completely banned there... We ought to be truly grateful for having the freedom to celebrate together.

Today is Christmas, as you know, ~player~. But did you know that the first known Christmas celebration took place in Rome on this day in 336 CE? December 25 was chosen as the day it was the date of the winter solstice on the Roman calendar and it was nine months after March 25, the date of the vernal equinox and a date linked to the conception of Jesus.
In addition to Christmas, this day in 1000 CE marked the foundation of the {b}Kingdom of Hungary{!reset}! It was established as a Christian kingdom by Stephen I of Hungary.

On this day in 758, {b}Halley's Comet{!reset} was sighted by Johann Georg Palitzsch, confirming Edmund Halley's prediction of its passage. This was the first passage of a comet predicted ahead of time.
On this day in 1946, the first European {b}self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction{!reset} was initiated within the Soviet Union's F-1 nuclear reactor.

In addition to religious significance, today has a certain significance for the Sapce Race, as on this day in 1968, {b i}Apollo 8{!reset} performed the first successful Trans-Earth injection (TEI) maneuver, sending the crew and spacecraft on a trajectory back to Earth from Lunar orbit!
On Christmas Day in 2004, NASA's Cassini orbiter released the {b i}Huygens{b} probe{!reset}, which successfully landed on Saturn's moon Titan twelve days later!

Today is the birthday of English physicist and mathematician {b}Isaac Newton{!reset}! ...Well, at least according to the Julian--or "Old Style"--calendar. Both it and the Gregorian--"New Style"--calendar were in use during Newton's lifetime.
American actor {b}Humphrey Bogart{!reset} was born on this day in 1899! So that must be why he was so grumpy in Casablanca; he never got to have a proper birthday celebration!
Hi-De-Hi-De-Hi-De-Ho! American jazz singer {b}Cab Calloway{!reset}, best known for his hit song, "Minnie the Moocher," was born on this day in 1907!

I know it is after Halloween, but here is a spooky fun fact this Christmas: Did you know that {b}Rod Serling{!reset}, the American screenwriter and producer who created the eerie science fiction and horror anthology series The Twilight Zone and Night Gallery, was born on this day in 1924?
Happy birthday, {b}Sissy Spacek{!reset}! The American actress, perhaps most widely known for portraying the titular character in the 1977 horror film Carrie, was born on this day in 1949.

All I want for Christmas... is to know what Sweet Dreams are made of. But Scottish singer-songwriter {b}Annie Lennox{!reset} famously answered that question! The lead singer of English pop duo Eurythmics, known for their hits including "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)," was born on this day in 1954.
The hymn "{b}Silent Night{!reset}" was performed for the first time on this day in 1818, at the Church of St. Nikolaus in Oberndorff, Austria.

On this day in 19597, a 17-year-old boy named Richard Starkey received his first drum set for Christmas. He would later be known as {b}Ringo Starr{!reset}, and would play in many bands before achieving success in the Beatles! Just goes to show that the right gift can make a difference. And speaking of which, why don't you help make a difference with your gift of just a few dollars?
The winter holiday season is a popular time for movies to be released. Christmas day in 2014 alone saw the release of Into the Woods, Unbroken, Selma, American Sniper, and Big Eyes.

Did you know that The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl had a sequel? No? Well, that may be because Robert Rodriguez's film {b i}We Can Be Heroes{!reset}, released on this day in 2020, was never released to theaters and was competing against other films such as Soul and Wonder Woman 1984.

Christmas Day seems to be a popular day for the release of musical movie adaptations. Evita in 1996, Dreamgirls in 2006, Les Misérables in 2012, and Into the Woods in 2014 were all released on this day in their respective years and all based on popular stage musicals.

Unlike other days, when I struggle to come up with fun facts for the day, I almost have too many for December 25! So be sure to visit Wikipedia itself if you are interested in more facts about this day!

On this day in 2021, NASA, in collaboration with the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA), launched the {b}James Webb Space Telescope{!reset} ({b}JWST{!reset})! In development since the 1990s, the JWST is the successor to the earlier Hubble Space Telescope and is said to be even more powerful!

Happy {b}Boxing Day{!reset}, ~player~! In the Commonwealth of Nations, Boxing Day is the day after Christmas and is primarily known as a shopping holiday, though it originated as a holiday to give gifts to the poor. Surprisingly, it is not a day dedicated to pugilists.

Dramatist W. S. Gilbert and composer Arthur Sullivan would collaborate on the creation of fourteen comic operas, the first of which, {b i}Thespis{!reset}, premiered at the Gaiety Theatre in London on this day in 1871! However, the two would not collaborate again for four years and the score has been lost.
On this day in 1898, Marie and Pierre Curie announced the discovery of the element {b}radium{!reset} ({b}Ra{!reset}, atomic number 88).

On this day in 1941, U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed a bill establishing the fourth Thursday in November as {b}Thanksgiving Day{!reset} in the United States. Although Thanksgiving celebrations had been established by Abraham Lincoln to be set on the last Thursday of November, Roosevelt moved the date to the fourth Thursday, where it stands today.

On this day in 1963, a little band called {b}the Beatles{!reset} released their singles "I Want to Hold Your Hand" and "I Saw Her Standing There" in the United States. This marked the beginning of the phenomenon known as Beatlemania on an international level. What are your favorite Beatles songs, ~player~?
Happy birthday, {b}Lars Ulrich{!reset}! Certainly a controversial figure in the music world, the drummer and co-founder of heavy metal band Metallica was born on this day in 1963.

{b}Jared Leto{!reset}, the American actor and musician most famous as the frontman of the band 30 Seconds to Mars--and most infamous for his role as the Joker in Suicide Squad--was born on this day in 1971.
Happy birthday, {b}Chris Daughtry{!reset}! The lead singer of the American pop rock band Daughtry was born on this day in 1979.
On this day in 1967, the Beatles' film {b i}Magical Mystery Tour{!reset} premiered on BBC-TV.

William Friedkin's acclaimed horror film {b i}The Exorcist{!reset} was released on this day in 1973. Interesting how it is more associated with the Halloween season, yet was released closer to Christmas...

The {b}Tupolev Tu-144{!reset}, the world's first commercial supersonic aircraft, surpassing Mach 2, went into service on this day in 1975. Unfortunately, reliability, developmental issues, and rising fuel prices led to it being retired from passenger service three years later.

On this day in 1966, the first {b}Kwanzaa{!reset} was celebrated by Maulana Karenga, the chair of Black Studies at California State University, Long Beach. Kwanzaa is an annual celebration of African-American culture that is held from December 26 to January 1. Do you celebrate Kwanzaa, ~player~??
The stageplay {b i}Peter Pan; or, The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up{!reset}, by Scottish author and dramatist J. M. Barrie, premiered in London on this day in 1904.

On this day in 537 CE, the construction of the {b}Hagia Sophia{!reset} in Constantinople was completed. It was the patriarchal cathedral of the imperial capital of Constantinople and was the world's largest cathedral for nearly a thousand years.

On this day in 1831, Charles Darwin embarked on his journey aboard the HMS Beagle, during which he began to formulate his theory of evolution. Going on journeys across the world can be a good way of learning more, but sometimes it is simply easier to read articles on Wikipedia.
I think I caused quite a mess back there! But hopefully not as much of a mess as the {b}Lewes avalanche{!reset}, the worst ever avalanche in England, which occurred at Sussex on this day in 1836.
On this day in 1922, the Japanese aircraft carrier {b i}Hōshō{!reset} (literally "phoenix flying") became the world's first commissioned ship that was built as an aircraft carrier.

The musical {b i}Show Boat{!reset}, with music by Jerome Kern and book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein II, opened at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Broadway on this day in 1927. It is considered to be the first true American musical play.

On this day in 1968, {b i}Apollo 8{!reset} splashed down in the Pacific Ocean, ending the first orbital manned mission to the Moon! I have always wanted to go to the Moon... do you think I might be able to in the future, ~player~?

{b}Thea von Harbou{!reset}, the German actress, director, and screenwriter best known for her collaborations with her husband, film director Fritz Lang, on films such as Metropolis, M, and The Testament of Dr. Mabuse, was born on this day in 1888.

Happy birthday, {b}Mike Pinder{!reset}! The founding keyboardist of the British rock group the Moody Blues, known for his technological contributions to music through his use of the Mellotron and Chamberlin, was born on this day in 1941.
Happy birthday, {b}David Knopfler{!reset}! Born on this day in 1952, the guitarist is most famous for co-founding the band Dire Straits with his brother, Mark Knopfler.

{b}Mick Jones{!reset}, the lead guitarist of the British-American rock band Foreigner, was born on this day in 1944. He is not to be confused with Mick Jones, the lead guitarist of British punk band The Clash.

Happy birthday, {b}Peter Sinfield{!reset}! The English poet and songwriter best known as the co-founder and former lyricist of King Crimson, having written all the lyrics on their debut album In the Court of the Crimson King, was born on this day in 1943.
{b}Radio City Music Hall{!reset} opened its doors to the public for the first time on this day in 1932. It is still operating to this day!

On this day in 1970, {b i}Hello, Dolly!{!reset}, one of the longest running and most enduring musical theater hits, closed on Broadway after a run of 2,844 performances. It later had four Broadway revivals.
The state of {b}South Australia{!reset} and its capital city Adelaide were founded on this day in 1836.
Are you from {b}Iowa{!reset}, ~player~? Because I bet you did not know that Iowa was admitted as the 29th U.S. state on this day in 1846!
On this day in 1795, construction of {b}Yonge Street{!reset} began in York, Upper Canada (present-day Toronto). Yonge Street was formerly recognized as the longest street in the world.

On this day in 1895, Wilhelm Röntgen publishes a paper detailing his discovery of a new type of radiation, which later became known as {b}x-rays{!reset}. The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry later named element 111, roentgenium, in Röntgen's honor.

The {b}Lumière brothers{!reset}, Auguste and Louis, were among the earliest filmmakers and screened their first film, Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory, on this day in 1895. Of course, it was very short--only 46 seconds--and it was silent and in black and white, but it paved the way for what modern filmmakers can do today.
On this day in 1912, the {b}San Francisco Municipal Railway{!reset}, the first municipally owned streetcars, took to the streets in San Francisco.

Saying whether the game I just finished is among the greatest is subjective, of course. But did you know that the {b}1958 NFL Championship Game{!reset}, in which the Baltimore Colts defeated the New York Giants in the NFL's first ever sudden death overtime game at New York's Yankee Stadium, is widely known as the "Greatest Game Ever Played"?

On this day in 1973, the {b}United States Endangered Species Act{!reset} was signed into law. It was designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a "consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation."

Happy birthday, {b}Nichelle Nichols{!reset}! Born on this day in 1932, the American actress best known for playing Lieutenant Nyota Uhura on Star Trek: The Original Series, a character that was famous for showing a black woman in an equal position amidst the early Civil Rights Movement.

Come on and take a free ride! Happy birthday to American blues-rock singer-songwriter and keyboardist {b}Edgar Winter{!reset}! Born on this day in 1946, Winter was the younger brother of fellow musician Johnny Winter and played a number of instruments with proficiency, including saxophone, drums, and most famously synthesizer, which he pioneered.

Everybody dance now! {b}Martha Wash{!reset}, the singer famous for her work with the Weather Girls such as "It's Raining Men," and her session work for house music groups like C+C Music Factory with "Gonna Make You Sweat (Everybody Dance Now)," was born on this day in 1953.

On this day in 1982, bassist {b}Cliff Burton{!reset} joined the American thrash metal band Metallica. He remained in the group until his death in 1986, and played and wrote songs for some of their most acclaimed albums, including Ride the Lightning and Master of Puppets.

On this day in 1860, the Royal Navy launched the world's first iron-hulled armoured warship, the {b}HMS {b i}Warrior{!reset}, with a screw propeller and an iron hull and armor. They did this to counter the French Navy's Gloire, the world's first ironclad warship, which had launch on November 24 the previous year.

On this day in 875 CE, {b}Charles the Bald{!reset}, King of the Franks, was crowned as Holy Roman Emperor Charles II. Despite his name, Charles was said to be very hairy; him being "bald" was used ironically as a reference to his lack of land, at an age where his brothers had already been sub-kings for years.

Remember, ~player~, that history is tricky; sometimes we can never know the truth! On this day in 1607, {b}Pocahontas{!reset}, daughter of Powhatan leader Wahunsenacawh, successfully pleaded for the life of Captain John Smith after tribal leaders attempted to execute him; however, much like this game, that is thought to largely be fanfiction written by Smith himself. You cannot always believe what you read!
The United States annexed the {b}Republic of Texas{!reset} on this day in 1845, making it into the 28th state. Are you from Texas, ~player~?

On this day in 1913, Cecil B. DeMille started filming for {b i}The Squaw Man{!reset}, Hollywood's first feature film. DeMille would direct over 69 more films, both silent and sound films, in his lengthy career!

{b}Charles Goodyear{!reset}, an American self-taught chemist and manufacturing engineer who developed vulcanized rubber, was born on this day in 1800. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was named after him!

{b}Ray Thomas{!reset}, the English singer-songwriter and flute player best known as the flautist, saxophonist, and co-lead singer of the Moody Blues, was born on this day in 1941. Do you like any of the Moody Blues' music, ~player~?

Take a load off, ~player~! Take a load for free! {b}Rick Danko{!reset}, the bassist and co-lead singer of Canadian-American rock band The Band, was born on this day in 1943. As vague a name as "The Band" is, feel free to peruse our page on "Band (disambiguation)" if you want any other types of bands.
Well, you saw many of us go topless today... but at least "topless" is not our last name! Unlike {b}David Topliss{!reset}, the English rugby league player and coach who was born on this day in 1949.

Are you familiar with classic rock, ~player~? Then perhaps you know that the today is the birthday of English rock drummer {b}Cozy Powell{!reset}! Born on this day in 1947, Powell was known for his work with The Jeff Beck Group, Rainbow, Gary Moore, Robert Plant, Brian May, Whitesnake, Black Sabbath, and Emerson, Lake & Powell.

Happy birthday, {b}Dexter Holland{!reset}! The American singer-songwriter is best known as the frontman of the punk band The Offspring, but he is also an accomplished scientist with a PhD in molecular biology. He is definitely "pretty fly for a white guy."

Italian director Serio Leone's classic spaghetti western {b i}The Good, the Bad and the Ugly{!reset} was released in theaters on this day in 1967. But... who in this game would be the good, the bad, and the ugly? I know I would be the good, but would you be the bad or the ugly, ~player~?
The {b}Ginza Line{!reset}, the first subway line in Asia, opened in Tokyo, Japan on this day in 1927.

Indian-English author and poet {b}Rudyard Kipling{!reset}, best known for his works of fiction such as The Jungle Book and "The Man Who Would Be King," was born on this day in 1865. Have you seen any film adaptations of his work, ~player~?

Happy birthday, {b}Russ Tamblyn{!reset}! Born on this day in 1934, Tamblyn, along with Richard Beymer, was one of two actors to appear in both the 1961 film West Side Story and the 1990 television drama Twin Peaks; in the former as Riff, the leader of the Jets gang, and in the latter as Dr. Lawrence Jacoby.
Happy birthday, {b}Noel Paul Stookey{!reset}! Born on this day in 1937, Stookey is best known as the Paul in American folk trio Peter, Paul and Mary.

{b}Michael Nesmith{!reset}, born on this day in 1942, was best known as the lead guitarist of pop group The Monkees; however, did you know that he had a successful songwriting career after leaving The Monkees and also created the music television series PopClips, the predecessor to what would become MTV?

Happy birthday, {b}Lloyd Kaufman{!reset}! Born on this day in 1945, Kaufman was the co-founder of the film studio Troma Entertainment, and directed many of their feature films, including The Toxic Avenger.

Jesus died for somebody's sins, but not mine...
These famous words were sung by American singer-songwriter and poet {b}Patti Smith{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1946! She is not to be confused with the similarly-named Patty Smyth, the lead singer of American rock band Scandal, which itself is not to be confused with the similarly-named Japanese rock band SCANDAL... oh no, I have gone cross-eyed.

You may have seen some strange magic tonight after my forfeit... and on that note, happy birthday to the writer of the song "Strange Magic," {b}Jeff Lynne{!reset}! Born on this day in 1947, Lynne is the frontman, lead guitarist, and core member of the progressive rock band Electric Light Orchestra! Are you familiar with their music, ~player~??
Happy {b}New Year's Eve{!reset}, ~player~! I look forward to seeing you around for another year of fun at the Inventory!

On this day in 1759, Irish brewer Arthur Guinness signed a 9,000 year lease at £45 per annum and started brewing {b}Guinness{!reset}, an Irish dry stout that is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide today!
Are you from Baltimore, Maryland, ~player~? If not, then have you ever been there? Either way, you should know that Baltimore was incorporated as a city on this day in 1796!

Thomas Edison demonstrated {b}incandescent lighting{!reset} to the public for the first time on this day in 1879, in Menlo Park, New Jersey. To think, if we never figured out lighting, you would not be seeing me right now...

English sculptor Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins and biologist Sir Richard Owen were known for having over two dozen lifesize sculptures of various prehistoric animals built out of concrete sculpted over a steel and brick framework. And on this day in 1853, they held a dinner party inside a life-size model of an {b}iguanodon{!reset}, a dinosaur species! I wonder if anyone has tried playing strip poker there...

This day in 1965 saw the first flight of the {b}Tupolev Tu-144{!reset}, the first civilian supersonic transport in the world! Although it would not be used for very long, it was still a masterful work of airflight mechanics.

This day in 2009 saw an interesting astronomical phenomenon: Both a {b}blue moon{!reset} (when there are two full moons in a month) and a {b}lunar eclipse{!reset} happened on the same day! Although, since lunar eclipses tend to turn the Moon a reddish hue, would that technically make it a red moon? Or maybe a purple moon, if you blend the red and blue...
It sure got hot to~background.time~! But not as hot as the {b}Dupont Plaza Hotel arson{!reset}, which occurred at the Hotel Dupont Plaza in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on this day in 1986.

Taiwan's {b}TAIPEI 101{!reset}, formerly the world's tallest building and the world's first skyscraper to exceed half a kilometer, was officially opened to the public on this day in 2004. It became known for its immense fireworks displays on New Year's Day. Although I certainly put on a display of a different kind, there is nothing like a good fireworks show.

On this day in 2011, the first of NASA's two {b}Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory{!reset} ({b}GRAIL{!reset}) satellites was successfully put in orbit around the Moon. The two small spacecraft GRAIL A (Ebb) and GRAIL B (Flow) used high-quality gravitational field mapping of the Moon to determine its interior structure.

Do you like the early British invasion band The Animals, ~player~? What about new wave band The Police? Both British bands have one member in common: guitarist {b}Andy Summers{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1942!
Well, I would certainly say I'm looking for some hot stuff, baby, this evening... In the immortal words of the great singer-songwriter {b}Donna Summer{!reset}, who was born on this day in 1948!

Did you know that most players of Strip Poker Night at the Inventory are metalheads, ~player~? ...Okay, I made that fact up, but regardless, this is a good time to mention that {b}Scott Ian{!reset}, the rhythm guitarist and co-founder of the thrash metal band Anthrax, was born on this day in 1963!

Scottish YouTuber and fellow educator and internet personality {b}Scott Manley{!reset} was born on this day in 1972! Manley primarily talks about space and rocket science while playing space-themed video games like Kerbal Space Program and explaining the science behind it. To use his signature catchphrase, fly safe!

On this day in 1984, Def Leppard drummer {b}Rick Allen{!reset} lost his left arm in a vehicle accident in England. Thankfully, he managed to overcome his new disability and continue drumming with a custom-made kit! This just shows that there are few things that you cannot overcome. Never give up on your goals, ~player~!
Happy {b}New Year's Day{!reset}, ~player~! I hope you have a fantastic year ahead of you!

On this day in 2019, the NASA space probe New Horizons flew by the trans-Neptunian object {b}486958 Arrokoth{!reset}, making it the farthest object visited by a spacecraft! I have always wanted to visit the outer reaches of our solar system, but until then, photos will have to do.

In addition to being New Year's Day, did you know that January 1 is also {b}Public Domain Day{!reset}? This is an observance of when copyrights expire and works enter into the public domain, although works fall into the public domain at different times depending on the individual copyright laws of each country. Personally, I am quite fond of the public domain, but that may not be surprising.
On this day in 42 BCE, the Roman Senate posthumously {b}deified{!reset} Julius Caesar. Do you think I may ever be remembered as a god, ~player~?

Though January 1 is observed as the start of a new year in most places, it is not seen as such everywhere; in fact, it was only this day in 1600 that {b}Scotland{!reset} recognized January 1 as the start of the new year, instead of March 25.

{b}Bouvet Island{!reset}, the world's most remote island, was discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier on this day in 1739. It is situated in the South Atlantic Ocean at the southern end of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. And do not worry; it is still mostly uninhabited, as it was designated as a nature reserve in 1971.

{b}Ceres{!reset}, the largest and first known object in the Asteroid belt, was discovered by Giuseppe Piazzi on this day in 1801! Ceres's status has been contested through time; it was originally considered a planet, then was reclassified as an asteroid in the 1850s, and then was changed again to a dwarf planet in 2006. Luckily, nobody ever gets upset when a planet is reclassified as a dwarf planet... right?

Do you believe that phone prices nowadays are bad, ~player~? For many years, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company (AT&T) owned a monopoly on the telephone market with 22 separate companies. It was only on this day in 1984 that the United States Department of Justice filed an {b}antitrust suit against AT&T{!reset}, breaking it into several companies. I wonder if other monopolies could still be broken today...

{b}Paul Revere{!reset}, born on this day in 1735, was an American silversmith and engraver best known for his midnight ride to alert the colonial militia in April 1775 to the approach of British forces before the battles of Lexington and Concord. However, he actually failed in delivering his message, just like how I may have failed at this game, but am still immortalized in the SPNatI roster.

Happy birthday, {b}Country Joe McDonald{!reset}! Born on this day in 1946, the American singer-songwriter and guitarist was best known as the frontman of Country Joe and the Fish, who famously performed at Woodstock Festival in 1969.

I know it has been many years, ~player~, but some are still upset that Pluto was demoted to a dwarf planet. Well, imagine a planet being demoted from existent to non-existent. Such is the case of the planet {b}Vulcan{!reset}, a planet between Mercury and the Sun whose discovery was announced by French mathematician Urbain Le Verrier on this day in 1860, but would later be disproved by Einstein's theory of general relativity, in one of the classic historic cases of "Boy, were they wrong!"

I may have failed at the game, but every failure leads to many great successes. Just ask {b i}Luna 1{!reset}, the Soviet Union's first attempt at launching a probe to the Moon, which occurred on this day in 1959. It missed the Moon by 5,900 kilometers, more than three times the Moon's radius, and wound up orbiting the Sun! Still, they did not give up, and many more probes were successfully launched to the Moon.

American science fiction author and biochemistry professor {b}Isaac Asimov{!reset} was born on this day in 1920. He wrote many famous works, including the Foundation series, I, Robot, and "The Bicentennial Man." Have you read any of his works, ~player~?

On this day in 1964, {b}the Beatles{!reset} made their first appearance on U.S. television in a film clip shown on The Jack Parr Show, where they performed "She Loves You." This moment sparked the phenomenon known as Beatlemania in the US.

The {b}Lick Observatory{!reset}, despite having a very... sexual sounding name, was in fact a real place, owned and operated by the University of California, and was known at one time for having the largest telescope in the world! Their 36-inch (91 cm) refracting telescope was used for the first time on this day in 1888.
On this day in 1870, construction work began on the {b}Brooklyn Bridge{!reset} in New York.

Proceedings of the {b}United States Congress{!reset} were televised for the first time on this day in 1947. Although given how many politicians heavily utilize platforms like Twitter today, the public proceedings of politicians may be a double-edged sword.

On this day in 1999, the {b}Mars Polar Lander{!reset} was launched by NASA. It was set to study the soil and climate of Planum Australe, a region near the south pole on Mars; however, after the descent stage, it failed to reestablish communication with Earth. As sad as that is, though, we must not forget that every failure is the gateway to many successes.

On this day in 2019, China's {b}Chang'e 4{!reset} probe made humanity's first soft landing on the far side of the Moon, and deployed the {b}Yutu-2{!reset} lunar rover! The quest for knowledge about our universe always exites me, ~player~. What about you?

On this day, back in 1989, specifically at Tiananmen Square in the People's Republic of China... nothing happened. Nothing at all!

On this day, back in 1500, {b}Pedro Álvares Cabral{!reset} anchored off the coast of present-day Brazil with his fleet, claiming the land for the Portuguese Empire.

On this day in 1864, the U.S. Congress authorized the creation of a {b}two-cent coin{!reset}, the first U.S. currency to bear the phrase {b}"In God We Trust."{!reset} The coin has fallen out of use, but the phrase has stuck around.

Today was the birthday of actor {b}Jack Nicholson{!reset}, famous for his role in The Shining!

On this day, but in 1978, John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd made their first appearance as {b}The Blues Brothers {!reset}on NBC's Saturday Night Live!

This day in 1964 marked the opening of the {b}New York World's Fair{!reset} in Flushing Meadows, Queens. The fair was noted as a showcase of mid-20th-century American culture and technology, including tech from the Space Age.

This day marks the birthday of {b}Steve Clark{!reset} in 1950, lead guitarist of the hard rock band Def Leppard, famous for their hit song, "Pour Some Sugar on Me"! Which does not seem very sanitary, now that I think about it...

On this day, but back in 1993, the film Benny and Joon was released to theaters.

In the United Nations, April 23 is the UN English Language Day. It is also celebrated as the UN Spanish Language Day. Weird...

On this day in 1800, the {b}Library of Congress{!reset}, the de facto national library of the United States, was established as part of an act of Congress to transfer the nation's capital from Philadelphia to Washington, D.C.

On this day in 1961, a young {b}Bob Dylan{!reset} earned a $50 session fee for playing harmonica on Harry Belafonte's "Midnight Special" in his first recording gig. Incidentally, $50 is about one-fifth of what an average Bob Dylan concert ticket costs nowadays!
On this day in 1968, Apple Records refused to sign a young David Bowie, which we at Wikipedia have listed under Category:Boy Were They Wrong!
On this day in 1901, New York became the first U.S. state to require automobile license plates.
On this day in 1983, space probe Pioneer 10 became the first human-made object to travel beyond Pluto's orbit and leave the solar system! Go Pioneer!
Happy National DNA Day! April 25 is celebrated in the United States to commemorate the publication of scientific findings about DNA in 1953!
This day in 1792 marked the first execution by guillotine. Dark, I know, but not every fact I have is uplifting.
On this day in 1960, the U.S. Navy submarine {b}Triton{!reset} completed {b}the first submerged circumnavigation of the world{!reset}.

This day in 2019 saw the release of {b}Avengers: Endgame,{!reset} which displaced James Cameron's Avatar as the highest grossing film of all time and held that title for a year before Avatar beat it again. Funny how that works!
On this day in 1962, NASA's {b}Ranger 4{!reset} spacecraft successfully landed on the Moon! ...Well, it crashed. So it failed successfully?
On this day in 1564, the Bard himself, {b}William Shakespeare{!reset}, was baptized in Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire, England! His actual birthdate is unknown.
This day in 1977 saw the opening of {b}Studio 54{!reset} in New York! A famous venue for the disco era, which I sadly arrived three decades too late for.
Today is best know as the day of the infamous {b}Chernobyl disaster{!reset} in 1986. Dark, I know, but not every fact I have is uplifting.
Happy {b}World Intellectual Property Day{!reset}, ~player~!
On this day in 1961, {b}Sierra Leone{!reset} was granted its independence from the United Kingdom.
Today is an important day in technology, ~player~! Because today in 1981, Xerox PARC introduced the {b}computer mouse{!reset} into the marketplace with its Xerox Star computer!
On this day in 1994, South Africa held the first democratic general election in which black citizens could vote. April 27 is now celebrated as {b}Freedom Day{!reset} in South Africa.
This day in 1932 was the birthday of DJ and voice actor {b}Casey Kasem{!reset}, best known as the co-creator of American Top 40 and as the original voice of Shaggy Rogers in Scooby-Doo.
Get up! Everybody's gonna move their feet! This day was the birthday of {b}Ace Frehley{!reset}, lead guitarist of American rock band KISS, in 1952.

On this day in 1789, near the island of Tofua, Fletcher Christian, acting lieutenant on board the Royal Navy ship Bounty, led {b}a mutiny{!reset} against the commander, William Bligh, in one of the most famous mutinies in history.
On this day in 1910, Frenchman Louis Paulhan won the {b}London to Manchester air race{!reset}, the first long-distance aeroplane race in England.
American entrepreneur {b}Dennis Tito{!reset} became the world's first fee-paying space tourist, riding the Russian Soyuz TM-32 spacecraft to the International Space Station on this day in 2001.
On this day in 1923, London's {b}Wembley Stadium{!reset} was opened! It held a number of football matches and music shows, including Queen's famous performance at Live Aid in 1985.
On this day in 1973, Pink Floyd's concept album The Dark Side of the Moon went to number one on the US Billboard chart, beginning a record-breaking 741-week chart run!
This day in 2003 was the opening of the iTunes Store, which sold over 70 million songs within its first year of operation.

On this day in 1968, the controversial musical {b}Hair,{!reset} a product of the hippie counter-culture and sexual revolution of the 1960s, opened on Broadway! Give me a head with hair! Long, beautiful hair!

On his first voyage, British explorer James Cook and the crew of {b}HMS Endeavour{!reset} landed at Botany Bay near present-day Sydney, making the first recorded European contact with the eastern coast of Australia on this day in 1770.
This day in 1970 was the birthday of American actress {b}Uma Thurman{!reset}, a personal favorite of both director Quentin Tarantino and rock band Fall Out Boy.
Did you know that UNESCO considers today {b}International Dance Day?{!reset} What's your favorite type of dance, ~player~?
On this day in 1826, Scottish astronomer James Dunlop discovered the galaxy {b}Centaurus A{!reset}, or NGC 5128.
Just like how this game is ending soon, on this day in 1945, World War II was ending in Germany.
On this day in 1598, King Henry IV of France issued the {b}Edict of Nantes{!reset}, granting freedom of religion to the Huguenots.
On this day in 1977, {b}Led Zeppelin{!reset} played a show to an audience of 77,229 in Pontiac, Michigan, which set a new record for attendance at a single-act concert.

This day in 1803 was the signing of the {b}Louisiana Purchase{!reset}, in which the United States purchased the Louisiana Territory from France for $15 million, more than doubling the size of the young nation.
On this day in 1812, the Territory of Orleans became the 18th U.S. state under the name Louisiana.
On this day in 1938, the animated cartoon short Porky's Hare Hunt debuted in movie theaters. It introduced Happy Rabbit, an early version of Bugs Bunny.

This day was the opening of the {b}New York World's Fair{!reset} in 1939. It was the second-most expensive American world's fair of all time and was the first exposition to be based on the future, with an opening slogan of "Dawn of a New Day", and it allowed all visitors to take a look at "the world of tomorrow."
Today is {b}International Workers' Day{!reset}, also known as {b}May Day{!reset} in some places!
Did you know that this day saw the premiere of Orson Welles' acclaimed film {b}Citizen Kane{!reset} in 1941?
On this day in 1865, the Empire of Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay signed the {b}Treaty of the Triple Alliance{!reset}.

On this day in 1956, {b}Jonas Salk{!reset} made his polio vaccine available to the public.
On this day in 2009, same-sex marriage was legalized in Sweden.
On this day in 1786, Mozart's opera {b}The Marriage of Figaro{!reset} premiered in Vienna, Austria.
On this day in 1972, {b}Paul Simon{!reset} released his self-titled solo debut album after splitting from Simon and Garfunkel.

Today is the United Nations' {b}World Press Freedom Day{!reset}, observed to raise awareness of the importance of freedom of the press and remind governments of their duty to respect and uphold the right to freedom of expression enshrined under Article 19 of the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Happy {b}Constitution Memorial Day{!reset}! If you are Japanese, that is. This day in takes place in celebration of the enactment of the 1947 Constitution of Japan and is a part of the collection of holidays known as Golden Week.
In 1921, on this day, {b}Ireland was partitioned{!reset} into two self-governing territories, Northern and Southern Ireland, under the British Government of Ireland Act.

On this day in 1979, {b}Margaret Thatcher{!reset} won the United Kingdom General Election and became their Prime Minister. Years later, after her death in 2013, the British public would get "Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead" charting in her honor!

On this day in 1960, {b}The Fantasticks{!reset} held its first off-Broadway show. The original production ran a total of 42 years (until 2002) and 17,162 performances, making it the world's longest-running musical!
On this day in 1988, Queensrÿche released their third album, {b}Operation: Mindcrime!{!reset} The album, a rock opera, has since become known as one of the greatest metal albums ever released.
Happy {b}Star Wars Day{!reset}, ~player~! May 4 was chosen for the pun on the catchphrase "May the Force be with you" as "May the Fourth be with you."

On this day in 1927, the {b}Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences{!reset} was incorporated.

On this day in 1932, notorious mobster {b}Al Capone{!reset} began serving an eleven-year prison sentence for tax evasion. Just goes to show, you can annoy the police and rival gangs, but ever mess with the IRS!
On this day in 1959, the 1st Annual Grammy Awards were held! But it is the Grammys, so nobody cared.
The 108-story {b}Sears Tower{!reset} in Chicago was topped out at 1,451 feet as the world's tallest building on this day in 1973.

This day in 2012 saw the release of {b}The Avengers,{!reset} which would become the third highest grossing film of all time.
Happy {b}Cinco de Mayo{!reset}, ~player~! This annual celebration is observed to commemorate the Mexican Army's victory over the French Empire at the Battle of Puebla, on May 5, 1862.

On this day in 1961, as part of Project Mercury, {b}Alan Shepard{!reset} made a sub-orbital flight aboard the Freedom 7, becoming the second person to travel into outer space.

If I recall correctly, tiki bars are exotic-themed drinking establishments that serve elaborate cocktails, especially rum-based mixed drinks such as the Mai Tai and Zombie cocktails. So I find strange that nobody offered us any drinks so far.
This bar, like all other tiki bars, seems aesthetically defined by its tiki culture décor. Which, by the way, is based upon a romanticized conception of tropical cultures, most commonly Polynesian.

See those faces in the background? Those are {b}tikis{!reset}. In Māori mythology, Tiki is the first man ever created, and these carvings in humanoid form represent either him or other deified ancestors in most Polynesian cultures.

case.state: {b i}Scott Pilgrim{!reset} is a series of graphic novels by Canadian author and comic book artist Bryan Lee O'Malley. The series is about Scott Pilgrim, a slacker and part-time musician who lives in Toronto, Ontario, and plays bass ‍in a band. He falls in love with American delivery girl Ramona Flowers, but must defeat her seven evil exes in order to date her in peace.
